title.raw: 卷一上 光武帝紀 Volume 1a: Annals of Emperor Guangwu

sentences.zh: 世祖光武皇帝諱秀，字文叔，〈禮「祖有功而宗有德」，光武中興，故廟稱世祖。

translations.literal: Emperor Shizu Guangwu's personal name was Xiu and his courtesy name was Wenshu. (The Book of Rites states, "Ancestors have merit and forebears have virtue." As Emperor Guangwu achieved a restoration, his temple name was Shizu.)
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Guangwu, whose personal name was Xiu and courtesy name was Wenshu, was posthumously titled Shizu. According to the Book of Rites, the title 'Ancestor' (Zu) is reserved for those of great merit; as he led the Han restoration, his temple name was accordingly designated Shizu.

sentences.zh: 謚法：「能紹前業曰光，克定禍亂曰武。」

translations.literal: The rules for posthumous names state: "One who can continue previous achievements is called Guang; one who can suppress disaster and chaos is called Wu."
translations.idiomatic: According to the system of posthumous titles: 'Guang' (Shining) denotes one who continues the legacy of their predecessors, while 'Wu' (Martial) signifies one who successfully quells disorder and rebellion.

sentences.zh: 伏侯《古今注》曰：「秀之字曰茂。

translations.literal: Marquis Fu's "Notes on Past and Present" states: "Xiu's courtesy name was Mao."
translations.idiomatic: The 'Notes on Past and Present' by Marquis Fu records that Xiu's courtesy name was also known as Mao.

sentences.zh: 伯、仲、叔、季，兄弟之次。

translations.literal: Bo, Zhong, Shu, and Ji represent the order of brothers.
translations.idiomatic: The terms Bo, Zhong, Shu, and Ji indicate the birth order of brothers from eldest to youngest.

sentences.zh: 長兄伯升，次仲，故字文叔焉。」〉南陽蔡陽人，〈南陽，郡，今鄧州縣也。

translations.literal: His eldest brother was Bosheng and the next was Zhong, so his courtesy name was Wenshu."
translations.idiomatic: As his eldest brother was Bosheng and his second brother was Zhong, his own courtesy name was designated Wenshu to reflect his position as the third son."

sentences.zh: 蔡陽，縣，故城在今隨州棗陽縣西南。〉高祖九世之孫也，出自景帝生長沙定王發。

translations.literal: Caiyang was a county; its ancient city was southwest of modern Zaoyang County in Suizhou.
translations.idiomatic: Caiyang was a county whose ancient administrative seat lay to the southwest of present-day Zaoyang in Suizhou.

sentences.zh: 〈長沙，郡，今潭州縣也。〉發生舂陵節侯買，〈舂陵，郷名，本屬零陵泠道縣，在今永州唐興縣北，元帝時徙南陽，仍號舂陵，故城今在隨州棗陽縣東。

translations.literal: (Changsha was a commandery, now Tanzhou.)
translations.idiomatic: (Changsha Commandery corresponds to the area of modern Tanzhou.)

sentences.zh: 事具宗室四王傳。〉買生鬱林太守外，〈鬱林，郡，今郴州縣。

translations.literal: The matters are detailed in the Biographies of the Four Kings of the Imperial Clan.
translations.idiomatic: Further details are recorded in the Biographies of the Four Kings of the Imperial Clan.

sentences.zh: 《前書》曰：「郡守，秦官。

translations.literal: The "Former Book" says: "The Commandery Administrator was a Qin official."
translations.idiomatic: The Book of Han (Former Book) states that the office of Commandery Administrator was a position established by the Qin dynasty."

sentences.zh: 秩二千石。

translations.literal: The rank was 2,000 piculs.
translations.idiomatic: The post carried an official rank and salary of 2,000 piculs of grain.

sentences.zh: 景帝更名太守。」〉外生鉅鹿都尉回，〈鉅鹿，郡，今邢州縣也。

translations.literal: Emperor Jing changed the name to Grand Administrator."
translations.idiomatic: During the reign of Emperor Jing, the title of the office was changed to Grand Administrator (Taishou)."

sentences.zh: 《前書》曰：「都尉，本郡尉，秦官也。

translations.literal: The "Former Book" says: "The Military Commandant was originally the Commandery Commandant, an office of the Qin dynasty."
translations.idiomatic: The Book of Han (Former Book) states that the office of Military Commandant was originally the Commandery Commandant, a position established by the Qin dynasty."

sentences.zh: 掌佐守，典武職，秩比二千石。

translations.literal: He was in charge of assisting the Grand Administrator and overseeing military duties, with a rank equivalent to 2,000 piculs.
translations.idiomatic: The officer was responsible for assisting the Grand Administrator and managing military affairs, holding a rank equivalent to 2,000 piculs.

sentences.zh: 景帝更名都尉。」〉回生南頓令欽，〈南頓，縣，屬汝南郡，故城在今陳州項城縣西。

translations.literal: Emperor Jing changed the name to Military Commandant."
translations.idiomatic: During the reign of Emperor Jing, the title of the office was changed to Military Commandant (Duwei)."

sentences.zh: 《前書》曰：「令、長，皆秦官也。

translations.literal: The "Former Book" says: "Magistrates and Chiefs were both offices of the Qin dynasty."
translations.idiomatic: The Book of Han (Former Book) states that the offices of Magistrate (Ling) and Chief (Zhang) were both established during the Qin dynasty."

sentences.zh: 萬戶以上為令，秩千石至六百石；

translations.literal: Counties with ten thousand households or more were headed by a Magistrate, with a rank ranging from 1,000 to 600 piculs;
translations.idiomatic: Counties with ten thousand or more households were headed by a Magistrate, whose rank ranged from 1,000 to 600 piculs;

sentences.zh: 不滿萬戶為長，秩五百石至三百石。」〉欽生光武。

translations.literal: those with fewer than ten thousand households were headed by a Chief, with a rank ranging from 500 to 300 piculs."
translations.idiomatic: those with fewer than ten thousand households were headed by a Chief, whose rank ranged from 500 to 300 piculs."

sentences.zh: 光武年九歲而孤，養於叔父良。

translations.literal: When Emperor Guangwu was nine years old, he was orphaned and was raised by his uncle Liu Liang.
translations.idiomatic: At the age of nine, the future Emperor Guangwu was orphaned and was subsequently raised by his uncle, Liu Liang.

sentences.zh: 身長七尺三寸，美須眉，大口，隆準，日角。

translations.literal: He stood seven chi and three cun tall, with a fine beard and eyebrows, a large mouth, a prominent nose, and a 'sun-horn' on his forehead.
translations.idiomatic: He stood seven chi and three cun tall, with a handsome beard and eyebrows, a wide mouth, a high-bridged nose, and a 'sun-horn' protrusion on his forehead.

sentences.zh: 〈隆，高也。

translations.literal: ('Long' means high or prominent.)
translations.idiomatic: ('Long' signifies a high or prominent feature.)

sentences.zh: 許負云：「鼻頭為準。」

translations.literal: The physiognomist Xu Fu said: "The tip of the nose is called the 'Zhun'."
translations.idiomatic: The physiognomist Xu Fu remarked: "The tip of the nose is referred to as the 'Zhun'."

sentences.zh: 鄭玄尚書中候注云：「日角謂庭中骨起，狀如日。」〉性勤於稼穡，〈種曰稼，斂曰穡。

translations.literal: Zheng Xuan, in his commentary on the 'Shangshu Zhonghou', said: "'Sun-horn' refers to a bony protrusion in the center of the forehead that is shaped like the sun."
translations.idiomatic: Zheng Xuan, in his commentary on the 'Shangshu Zhonghou', explained: "A 'sun-horn' refers to a bony protrusion in the middle of the forehead, shaped like the sun."

sentences.zh: 〈仲，郃陽侯喜也，能為產業。

translations.literal: (Zhong was Liu Xi, the Marquis of Heyang, who was capable at managing property.)
translations.idiomatic: (Zhong refers to Liu Xi, the Marquis of Heyang, who was known for his skill in managing the family estate.)

sentences.zh: 見《前書》。〉王莽天鳳中，〈王莽建國六年改為天鳳。

translations.literal: See the "Former Book".
translations.idiomatic: This is recorded in the Book of Han.

sentences.zh: 〈《東觀記》曰：「受尚書於中大夫廬江許子威。

translations.literal: (The "Records of the Eastern Pavilion" says: "He studied the Book of Documents under the Palace Grandee Xu Ziwei of Lujiang.)
translations.idiomatic: (The 'Records of the Eastern Pavilion' notes that he studied the Book of Documents under Xu Ziwei, a Palace Grandee from Lujiang.)

sentences.zh: 資用乏，與同舍生韓子合錢買驢，令從者僦，以給諸公費。」

translations.literal: His resources were lacking, so he pooled money with his roommate Han Zi to buy a donkey, and ordered an attendant to hire it out to provide for various shared expenses."
translations.idiomatic: Due to a lack of funds, he pooled his resources with his roommate, a student named Han, to purchase a donkey. They then had an attendant hire it out to cover their collective expenses."

sentences.zh: 莽末，天下連歲災蝗，寇盜鋒起。

translations.literal: At the end of Mang's reign, the empire suffered successive years of disasters and locusts, and bandits and thieves arose in sharp competition.
translations.idiomatic: In the final years of Wang Mang's reign, the empire was ravaged by consecutive years of famine and locust plagues, leading to a widespread outbreak of banditry and rebellion.

sentences.zh: 〈言賊鋒銳競起。

translations.literal: (Meaning the rebels' edge was sharp and they rose in competition.)
translations.idiomatic: (This indicates that the rebel forces were formidable and arose simultaneously.)

sentences.zh: 字或作「蜂」，諭多也。〉地皇三年，〈天鳳六年改為地皇。

translations.literal: The character is sometimes written as 'bee', illustrating their great numbers.)
translations.idiomatic: The character is sometimes written as 'bee' (swarm), to illustrate their overwhelming numbers.)

sentences.zh: 光武避吏新野，〈新野屬南陽郡，今鄧州縣。

translations.literal: Guangwu avoided officials in Xinye. (Xinye belonged to Nanyang Commandery, now in Dengzhou.)
translations.idiomatic: Guangwu went to Xinye to avoid the local authorities. (Xinye was a part of Nanyang Commandery, located in the region of modern Dengzhou.)

sentences.zh: 《續漢書》曰：「伯升賔客劫人，上避吏於新野鄧晨家。」〉因賣榖於宛。

translations.literal: The "Continued Book of Han" says: "Bosheng's retainers robbed people, and the Emperor avoided officials at Deng Chen's house in Xinye."
translations.idiomatic: The 'Continued Book of Han' records: 'When Bosheng's retainers were involved in a robbery, the future Emperor sought refuge from the authorities at the home of Deng Chen in Xinye.'

sentences.zh: 〈《東觀記》曰：「時南陽旱饑，而上田獨收。」

translations.literal: (The "Records of the Eastern Pavilion" says: "At that time, Nanyang suffered from drought and famine, but the Emperor's fields alone had a harvest.")
translations.idiomatic: (The 'Records of the Eastern Pavilion' notes: 'During that period, while Nanyang was stricken by drought and famine, the future Emperor's fields alone yielded a bountiful harvest.')

sentences.zh: 宛，縣，屬南陽郡，故城今鄧州南陽縣也。〉宛人李通等以圖讖說光武云：「劉氏復起，李氏為輔。」

translations.literal: Wan was a county belonging to Nanyang Commandery; its ancient city is now Nanyang County in Dengzhou.
translations.idiomatic: Wan was a county within Nanyang Commandery; its ancient administrative seat corresponds to modern Nanyang in the Dengzhou region.

sentences.zh: 〈圖，河圖也。

translations.literal: ('Tu' refers to the River Chart.)
translations.idiomatic: ('Tu' refers to the mystical River Chart.)

sentences.zh: 讖，符命之書。

translations.literal: 'Chen' refers to books of prophetic omens.
translations.idiomatic: 'Chen' refers to texts containing divine prophecies and omens.

sentences.zh: 讖，驗也。

translations.literal: 'Chen' means verification.
translations.idiomatic: 'Chen' also signifies the fulfillment or verification of a prophecy.

sentences.zh: 言為王者受命之徵驗也。

translations.literal: It means the evidence and verification of a king receiving the mandate.
translations.idiomatic: This refers to the signs and proofs that a sovereign has received the Mandate of Heaven.

sentences.zh: 《易坤靈圖》曰：「漢之臣李陽也。」〉光武初不敢當，然獨念兄伯升素結輕客，必舉大事，且王莽敗亡已兆，天下方亂，遂與定謀，於是乃市兵弩。

translations.literal: The "Kunling Chart of the Yi" says: "The minister of Han is Li Yang."
translations.idiomatic: The 'Kunling Chart of the Yi' states: 'The servant of Han shall be Li Yang.'

sentences.zh: 十月，與李通從弟軼等起於宛，時年二十八。

translations.literal: In the tenth month, he rose in Wan with Li Tong's cousin Li Yi and others; he was then twenty-eight years old.
translations.idiomatic: In the tenth month, at the age of twenty-eight, he launched his uprising in Wan alongside Li Yi, the cousin of Li Tong, and their associates.

sentences.zh: 十一月，有星孛于張。

translations.literal: In the eleventh month, a comet appeared in the constellation Zhang.
translations.idiomatic: In the eleventh month, a comet was sighted in the constellation of Zhang.

sentences.zh: 〈《前書》音義曰：「孛星光芒短，蓬然。

translations.literal: (The "Book of Han" Phonetics and Meanings says: "A comet's light and rays are short and bushy.")
translations.idiomatic: (The 'Phonetics and Meanings of the Book of Han' describes a comet as having short, bushy rays of light.)

sentences.zh: 張，南方宿也。」

translations.literal: Zhang is a southern lunar mansion.")
translations.idiomatic: Zhang is one of the lunar mansions of the south.")

sentences.zh: 《續漢志》曰：「張為周地。

translations.literal: The "Treatise of the Continued Book of Han" says: "The constellation Zhang corresponds to the land of Zhou."
translations.idiomatic: The 'Treatise of the Continued Book of Han' states: 'The constellation Zhang is associated with the territory of Zhou.'

sentences.zh: 星孛于張，東南行即翼、軫之分。

translations.literal: A comet appeared in Zhang and traveled southeast into the divisions of Yi and Zhen.
translations.idiomatic: When a comet appeared in Zhang and moved toward the southeast, it entered the celestial divisions corresponding to Yi and Zhen.'

sentences.zh: 翼、軫，楚地，是楚地將有兵亂。

translations.literal: Yi and Zhen correspond to the land of Chu; this means there will be military chaos in the land of Chu.
translations.idiomatic: As Yi and Zhen correspond to the land of Chu, this portended that military conflict would soon break out in that region.

sentences.zh: 後一年正月，光武起兵舂陵，攻南陽，斬阜、賜等，殺其士衆數萬人。

translations.literal: One year later in the first month, Guangwu raised troops in Chongling, attacked Nanyang, beheaded Fu and Ci, and killed tens of thousands of their soldiers.
translations.idiomatic: In the first month of the following year, Guangwu raised an army in Chongling and launched an attack on Nanyang, where he executed Zhen Fu and Liangqiu Ci and decimated their forces by the tens of thousands.

sentences.zh: 光武都雒陽，居周地，除穢布新之象。」〉光武遂將賔客還舂陵。

translations.literal: Guangwu made Luoyang his capital, residing in the land of Zhou, which was a sign of removing the old and spreading the new."
translations.idiomatic: Guangwu eventually established his capital at Luoyang, within the ancient lands of Zhou—a symbolic fulfillment of the omen to sweep away the old and usher in the new."

sentences.zh: 時伯升已會衆起兵。

translations.literal: At that time, Bosheng had already assembled a crowd and raised troops.
translations.idiomatic: By then, his brother Bosheng had already gathered a following and launched his military campaign.

sentences.zh: 初，諸家子弟恐懼，皆亡逃自匿，曰：「伯升殺我」。

translations.literal: Initially, the sons and younger brothers of various families were terrified and all fled to hide themselves, saying: "Bosheng will kill us."
translations.idiomatic: At the beginning, the young men of the local families were struck with terror and fled into hiding, exclaiming, 'Bosheng is going to get us killed!'

sentences.zh: 及見光武絳衣大冠，〈董巴輿服志曰：「大冠者，謂武冠，武官冠之。」

translations.literal: But when they saw Guangwu in crimson robes and a large hat (Dong Ba's "Treatise on Chariots and Robes" says: "The large hat refers to the martial hat, worn by military officials.")
translations.idiomatic: However, when they saw Guangwu appearing in crimson robes and a stately martial cap (which, as Dong Ba's 'Treatise on Chariots and Robes' notes, was the headgear reserved for military officers),

sentences.zh: 《東觀記》曰：「上時絳衣大冠，將軍服也。」〉皆驚曰：「謹厚者亦復為之」，乃稍自安。

translations.literal: The "Records of the Eastern Pavilion" says: "The Emperor at that time wore crimson robes and a large hat, which was the uniform of a general.")
translations.idiomatic: The 'Records of the Eastern Pavilion' likewise notes that his attire of crimson robes and a martial cap was the formal uniform of a general.)

sentences.zh: 伯升於是招新市、平林兵，〈新市，縣，屬江夏郡，故城在今郢州富水縣東北。

translations.literal: Bosheng then recruited troops from Xinshi and Pinglin. (Xinshi was a county belonging to Jiangxia Commandery; its ancient city was northeast of modern Fushui County in Yingzhou.)
translations.idiomatic: Bosheng then called upon the insurgent forces from Xinshi and Pinglin. (Xinshi was a county under Jiangxia Commandery, located northeast of present-day Fushui in Yingzhou.)

sentences.zh: 平林，地名，在今隨州隨縣東北。〉與其帥王鳳、陳牧西擊長聚。

translations.literal: Pinglin was a place name, northeast of modern Sui County in Suizhou.
translations.idiomatic: Pinglin was a location situated to the northeast of modern Sui County in Suizhou.

sentences.zh: 〈《廣雅》曰：「聚，居也，音慈諭反。」

translations.literal: (The "Guangya" says: "'Ju' means a settlement; the pronunciation is Ci-Yu reversed.")
translations.idiomatic: (The 'Guangya' defines 'Ju' as a settlement or village; its pronunciation is indicated as Ci-Yu reversed.)

sentences.zh: 《前書》音義曰：「小於郷曰聚。」〉光武初騎牛，殺新野尉乃得馬。

translations.literal: The Phonetics and Meanings of the "Book of Han" says: "A place smaller than a township is called a settlement."
translations.idiomatic: The 'Phonetics and Meanings of the Book of Han' defines a settlement (Ju) as a community smaller than a township.

sentences.zh: 〈《前書》曰，尉，秦官，秩四百石至二百石也。〉進屠唐子郷，〈例曰：「多所誅殺曰屠。」

translations.literal: (The "Book of Han" says the Commandant was a Qin office, with a rank ranging from 400 to 200 piculs.)
translations.idiomatic: (The Book of Han notes that the office of Commandant was established during the Qin dynasty, carrying a rank between 400 and 200 piculs.)

sentences.zh: 唐子郷有唐子山，在今唐州湖陽縣西南。〉又殺湖陽尉。

translations.literal: Tangzixiang has Mount Tangzi, which is southwest of modern Huyang County in Tangzhou.
translations.idiomatic: Tangzixiang is the location of Mount Tangzi, situated southwest of present-day Huyang in Tangzhou.

sentences.zh: 〈湖陽屬南陽郡，今唐州縣也。

translations.literal: (Huyang belonged to Nanyang Commandery, now in the region of modern Tangzhou.)
translations.idiomatic: (Huyang was a part of Nanyang Commandery, located in the modern Tangzhou area.)

sentences.zh: 《東觀記》曰：「劉終詐稱江夏吏，誘殺之。」〉軍中分財物不均，衆恚恨，欲反攻諸劉。

translations.literal: The "Records of the Eastern Pavilion" says: "Liu Zhong falsely claimed to be an official from Jiangxia and lured him to his death.")
translations.idiomatic: The 'Records of the Eastern Pavilion' records: 'Liu Zhong posed as an official from Jiangxia to lure the Commandant into an ambush and kill him.')

sentences.zh: 光武斂宗人所得物，悉以與之，衆乃恱。

translations.literal: Guangwu collected the items obtained by members of the imperial clan and gave them all to the soldiers, and the crowd was then pleased.
translations.idiomatic: Guangwu intervened by gathering all the property that the members of the imperial clan had collected and distributing it among the troops, which finally pacified and pleased the men.

sentences.zh: 進拔棘陽，〈縣名，屬南陽郡，在棘水之陽，古謝國也，故城在今唐州湖陽縣西北。

translations.literal: They advanced and captured Jiyang. (A county name, belonging to Nanyang Commandery, located on the north bank of the Ji River; it was the ancient State of Xie, and the ancient city is northwest of modern Huyang County in Tangzhou.)
translations.idiomatic: They advanced and seized Jiyang. (This county, a part of Nanyang Commandery, was situated on the north bank of the Ji River and was the site of the ancient State of Xie; its administrative seat lay northwest of present-day Huyang in Tangzhou.)

sentences.zh: 棘音己力反。〉與王莽前隊大夫甄阜、〈王莽置六隊，郡置大夫一人，職如太守。

translations.literal: (The pronunciation of 'Ji' is Ji-Li reversed.)
translations.idiomatic: (The pronunciation of the character 'Ji' is indicated by the reverse fanqie of Ji-Li.)

sentences.zh: 南陽為前隊，河內為後隊，潁川為左隊，弘農為右隊，河東為兆隊，滎陽為祈隊。

translations.literal: Nanyang was the Front Corps, Henei was the Rear Corps, Yingchuan was the Left Corps, Hongnong was the Right Corps, Hedong was the Zhao Corps, and Xingyang was the Qi Corps.
translations.idiomatic: Under this system, Nanyang was designated the Front Corps, Henei the Rear Corps, Yingchuan the Left Corps, Hongnong the Right Corps, Hedong the Zhao Corps, and Xingyang the Qi Corps.

sentences.zh: 隊音遂。〉屬正梁丘賜〈王莽每隊置屬正一人，職如都尉。

translations.literal: (The pronunciation of 'Dui' is Sui.)
translations.idiomatic: (The character 'Dui' (Corps) is pronounced here as 'Sui'.)

sentences.zh: 二月辛巳，立劉聖公為天子，以伯升為大司徒，光武為太常偏將軍。

translations.literal: On the Xinsi day of the second month, Liu Shenggong was established as the Son of Heaven, with Bosheng as Grand Minister over the Masses, and Guangwu as Grand Master of Ceremonies and Lieutenant General.
translations.idiomatic: On the Xinsi day of the second month, Liu Xuan (Shenggong) was enthroned as the Son of Heaven. He appointed Liu Bosheng as the Grand Minister over the Masses, while the future Emperor Guangwu was named Grand Master of Ceremonies and Lieutenant General.

sentences.zh: 〈《前書》曰：「奉常，秦官。

translations.literal: (The "Former Book" says: "The Attendant of Ceremonies was a Qin office.")
translations.idiomatic: (The Book of Han notes that the office of Attendant of Ceremonies was originally established by the Qin dynasty.)

sentences.zh: 景帝更名太常。」

translations.literal: Emperor Jing changed the name to Grand Master of Ceremonies."
translations.idiomatic: During the reign of Emperor Jing, the title of the office was changed to Grand Master of Ceremonies (Taichang)."

sentences.zh: 應劭漢官儀曰：「欲令國家盛大，社稷常存，故稱太常。」

translations.literal: Ying Shao's "Apparatus of Han Officials" says: "Wishing to make the state grand and great, and the altars of soil and grain last forever, it is thus called 'Taichang' (Grand Constant)."
translations.idiomatic: Ying Shao's 'Apparatus of Han Officials' explains: 'The title Taichang—meaning Grand Constant—was chosen in the hope that the state would remain grand and the altars of soil and grain would endure forever.'

sentences.zh: 老子曰：「偏將軍處左，上將軍處右。」

translations.literal: Laozi said: "The Lieutenant General stays on the left, and the General-in-Chief stays on the right."
translations.idiomatic: As recorded in the Laozi: 'The Lieutenant General is positioned on the left, while the General-in-Chief takes the place of honor on the right.'

sentences.zh: 《東觀記》曰：「時無印，得定武侯家丞印，佩之入朝。」

translations.literal: The "Records of the Eastern Pavilion" says: "At that time there were no seals; he obtained the seal of the family steward of the Marquis of Dingwu, and wore it to enter the court."
translations.idiomatic: The 'Records of the Eastern Pavilion' relates: 'At that time, no proper official seals were available; he had to use the seal of the family steward of the Marquis of Dingwu, which he wore when attending the imperial court.'

sentences.zh: 初，王莽徵天下能為兵法者六十三家數百人，並以為軍吏；

translations.literal: Earlier, Wang Mang summoned several hundred people from sixty-three schools across the empire who were capable in military strategy, and made them all military officers;
translations.idiomatic: Previously, Wang Mang had summoned several hundred experts representing sixty-three different schools of military strategy from across the empire, appointing them all as military officers;

sentences.zh: 選練武衞，招募猛士，〈《說文》曰：「募，廣求之也。」〉旌旗輜重，千里不絕。

translations.literal: He selected and trained the martial guards, and recruited brave warriors (The "Shuowen" says: "'Mu' means to seek widely.")
translations.idiomatic: He handpicked and trained elite martial guards and recruited formidable warriors from far and wide. (The 'Shuowen' dictionary defines the term '募' (recruit) as seeking out someone through a wide and extensive search.)

sentences.zh: 〈《周禮》曰：「析羽為旌，熊虎為旗。」

translations.literal: (The "Rites of Zhou" says: "Divided feathers make a 'Jing' banner; bear and tiger designs make a 'Qi' flag.")
translations.idiomatic: (According to the Rites of Zhou: 'Banners adorned with split feathers are called Jing, while those bearing the images of bears and tigers are called Qi.')

sentences.zh: 輜，車名。

translations.literal: 'Zi' is the name of a wagon.
translations.idiomatic: The term 'Zi' refers to a type of heavy supply wagon.

sentences.zh: 釋名曰：「輜，廁也。

translations.literal: The "Shiming" says: "'Zi' means mingled."
translations.idiomatic: The 'Shiming' (Explanation of Names) states that the term 'Zi' implies a mingling of different things.

sentences.zh: 謂軍糧什物雜廁載之。

translations.literal: It means military provisions and various items are loaded and mingled together.
translations.idiomatic: This refers to the practice of loading military provisions and various miscellaneous goods together in a mingled fashion.

sentences.zh: 以其累重，故稱輜重。」

translations.literal: Because they are accumulated and heavy, they are called 'Zizhong' (heavy baggage)."
translations.idiomatic: Due to the great weight and accumulation of these items, they are known collectively as 'Zizhong' or heavy baggage."

sentences.zh: 重音直用反。〉時有長人巨無霸，〈王莽連率韓博上言：「有竒士，長一丈，大十圍，自謂巨無霸，出於蓬萊東南五城西北，詔如海濵，軺車不能載，三馬不能勝，卧則枕鼓，以鐵箸食。」

translations.literal: (The pronunciation of 'Zhong' is indicated by the reverse fanqie of Zhi-Yong.)
translations.idiomatic: (The character 'Zhong' is pronounced here according to the reverse fanqie of the characters Zhi and Yong.)

sentences.zh: 見《前書》。〉長一丈，大十圍，以為壘尉；

translations.literal: See the "Former Book".
translations.idiomatic: This account is recorded in the Book of Han.

sentences.zh: 〈鄭玄注周禮云：「軍壁曰壘。」

translations.literal: (Zheng Xuan's commentary on the "Rites of Zhou" says: "The wall of an army camp is called a rampart.")
translations.idiomatic: (Zheng Xuan, in his commentary on the Rites of Zhou, notes: 'The defensive walls of an army camp are referred to as ramparts.')

sentences.zh: 崔瑗中壘校尉箴曰：「堂堂黃帝，設為壘壁。」

translations.literal: Cui Yuan's "Admonition for the Colonel of the Central Ramparts" says: "The majestic Yellow Emperor established ramparts and walls."
translations.idiomatic: Cui Yuan's 'Admonition for the Colonel of the Central Ramparts' states: 'The majestic Yellow Emperor himself established the precedent for building ramparts and defensive walls.'

sentences.zh: 尉者主壘壁之事。〉又驅諸猛獸〈「猛」或作「獷」。

translations.literal: The Commandant is in charge of matters concerning the ramparts and walls.
translations.idiomatic: The office of Commandant was responsible for the oversight of all matters concerning the camp's ramparts and walls.

sentences.zh: 獷，猛貌也，音古猛反。〉虎豹犀象之屬，以助威武。

translations.literal: 'Guang' means a fierce appearance; the pronunciation is the reverse fanqie of Gu-Meng.)
translations.idiomatic: The character 'Guang' signifies a fierce or savage appearance; its pronunciation is indicated by the reverse fanqie of Gu-Meng.)

sentences.zh: 自秦、漢出師之盛，未甞有也。

translations.literal: Since the rise of Qin and Han, such a grand military expedition had never occurred.
translations.idiomatic: Never before, since the dawn of the Qin and Han dynasties, had an army set forth with such overwhelming and unprecedented grandeur.

sentences.zh: 光武將數千兵，徼之於陽關。

translations.literal: Guangwu led several thousand troops to intercept them at Yangguan.
translations.idiomatic: Guangwu led a force of several thousand soldiers to intercept the advancing army at Yangguan.

sentences.zh: 〈聚名也。

translations.literal: (It is the name of a settlement.)
translations.idiomatic: (This is the name of a settlement.)

sentences.zh: 酈元水經注曰：「潁水東南經陽關聚，聚夾潁水相對。」

translations.literal: Li Daoyuan's "Commentary on the Water Classic" says: "The Ying River flows southeast through the Yangguan settlement; the settlement straddles the Ying River on both sides."
translations.idiomatic: Li Daoyuan, in his 'Commentary on the Water Classic', notes: 'The Ying River flows toward the southeast through the Yangguan settlement, which occupies both banks of the river.'

sentences.zh: 在今洛州陽翟縣西北。〉諸將見尋、邑兵盛，反走，馳入昆陽，皆惶怖，憂念妻孥，〈孥，子也。

translations.literal: It is northwest of modern Yangdi County in Luozhou.
translations.idiomatic: It is located to the northwest of present-day Yangdi in Luozhou.

sentences.zh: 光武議曰：「今兵糓旣少，而外寇彊大，并力禦之，功庶可立；

translations.literal: Guangwu argued: "Now our troops and grain are few, while the external enemy is powerful. If we join our forces to resist them, success might be achieved;
translations.idiomatic: Guangwu counselled them: 'Our soldiers are few and our supplies are low, while the enemy outside is formidable. Only by uniting our strength to resist them can we hope to achieve any success.'

sentences.zh: 如欲分散，勢無俱全。

translations.literal: If we want to disperse, there is no chance for all to remain safe.
translations.idiomatic: If we choose to scatter, none of us will survive the coming onslaught.'

sentences.zh: 且宛城未拔，〈謂伯升圍之未拔也。〉不能相救，昆陽即破，一日之閒，諸部亦滅矣。

translations.literal: Furthermore, the city of Wan has not yet been captured (referring to Bosheng's siege of it having not yet succeeded).
translations.idiomatic: Moreover, the city of Wan remains uncaptured (this refers to the ongoing siege by Liu Bosheng).

sentences.zh: 今不同心膽共舉功名，反欲守妻子財物邪？」

translations.literal: Now instead of being of one heart and courage to achieve merit and fame together, do you instead want to guard your wives, children, and property?"
translations.idiomatic: Rather than uniting our hearts and courage to win glory and merit together, do you truly intend to prioritize the safety of your families and possessions?'

sentences.zh: 諸將怒曰：「劉將軍何敢如是！」

translations.literal: The various generals said angrily: "How does General Liu dare to speak like this!"
translations.idiomatic: The other generals reacted with fury, exclaiming, 'How dare General Liu speak to us in such a manner!'

sentences.zh: 光武笑而起。

translations.literal: Guangwu laughed and stood up.
translations.idiomatic: Guangwu merely smiled and rose to his feet.

sentences.zh: 會候騎還，言大兵且至城北，軍陳數百里，不見其後。

translations.literal: Just then, the scout cavalry returned and said that the great army was about to reach the north of the city, with the army formation stretching for several hundred li, and its rear could not be seen.
translations.idiomatic: At that moment, the scouts returned with the news that the enemy's main force was approaching the north of the city. Their battle lines stretched for hundreds of li, and their rear was nowhere in sight.

sentences.zh: 諸將遽相謂曰：「更請劉將軍計之。」

translations.literal: The various generals hurriedly said to each other: "Let us again ask General Liu to plan for it."
translations.idiomatic: Terrified, the generals hurriedly conferred and agreed: 'We must ask General Liu to devise a plan after all.'

sentences.zh: 光武復為圖畫成敗。

translations.literal: Guangwu again mapped out the factors for success or failure for them.
translations.idiomatic: Guangwu then proceeded once more to outline the strategic possibilities for their success or failure.

sentences.zh: 諸將憂迫，皆曰「諾」。

translations.literal: The various generals, pressed by worry, all said: "Yes."
translations.idiomatic: Under the weight of their growing anxiety, the various generals all signified their assent.

sentences.zh: 時城中唯有八九千人，光武乃使成國上公王鳳、廷尉大將軍王常留守，夜自與驃騎大將軍宗佻、〈驃騎大將軍，武帝置，自霍去病始。

translations.literal: At that time, there were only eight or nine thousand people in the city. Guangwu then ordered the Superior Duke of Chengguo Wang Feng and the Commandant of Justice and General-in-Chief Wang Chang to stay and defend it; at night, he himself with General-in-Chief of Chariots and Cavalry Zong Tiao (the post of General-in-Chief of Chariots and Cavalry was established by Emperor Wu, beginning with Huo Qubing).
translations.idiomatic: At that time, the city was defended by only eight or nine thousand men. Guangwu assigned Wang Feng, the Superior Duke of Chengguo, and Wang Chang, the Commandant of Justice and General-in-Chief, to hold the city. Under the cover of night, he personally led Zong Tiao, the General-in-Chief of Chariots and Cavalry (a title first bestowed upon Huo Qubing by Emperor Wu),

sentences.zh: 佻音太堯反。〉五威將軍李軼等十三騎，〈王莽置五威將軍，其衣服依五方之色，以威天下。

translations.literal: (The pronunciation of 'Tiao' is the reverse fanqie of Tai-Yao.)
translations.idiomatic: (The name 'Tiao' is pronounced according to the reverse fanqie of Tai-Yao.)

sentences.zh: 李軼初起，猶假以為號。〉出城南門，於外收兵。

translations.literal: When Li Yi first rose up, he still used this as his title.
translations.idiomatic: At the start of the uprising, Li Yi continued to use this title for his own prestige.

sentences.zh: 時莽軍到城下者且十萬，光武幾不得出。

translations.literal: At that time, Mang's army reaching the city walls was nearly one hundred thousand; Guangwu was almost unable to get out.
translations.idiomatic: With Wang Mang's forces outside numbering nearly one hundred thousand, Guangwu and his men narrowly escaped being trapped within the city.

sentences.zh: 〈幾音祈。〉旣至郾、定陵，悉發諸營兵，而諸將貪惜財貨，欲分留守之。

translations.literal: (The pronunciation of 'Ji' is Qi.)
translations.idiomatic: (The character 'Ji' is pronounced as 'Qi' here.)

sentences.zh: 光武曰：「今若破敵，珍珤萬倍，〈珤，古「寶」字。〉大功可成；

translations.literal: Guangwu said: "Now if we defeat the enemy, our treasures will be ten thousand times greater ('Bao' is an ancient form of the character 'treasure').
translations.idiomatic: Guangwu admonished them: 'If we crush the enemy now, our rewards and treasures will be ten thousand times what we have here. ('Bao' is an archaic form of the character for treasure.)'

sentences.zh: 如為所敗，首領無餘，何財物之有！」

translations.literal: If we are defeated by them, our heads will not even be left, so what property would we have?"
translations.idiomatic: But if we are defeated, our very lives will be forfeit. What use then will your possessions be?'

sentences.zh: 衆乃從。

translations.literal: The crowd then followed him.
translations.idiomatic: The men were swayed by his words and followed his lead.

sentences.zh: 嚴尤說王邑曰：「昆陽城小而堅，今假號者在宛，亟進大兵〈亟，急也，音紀力反。〉，彼必奔走；

translations.literal: Yan You advised Wang Yi, saying: "Kunyang city is small but strong; now the one who uses the false title is in Wan. We should urgently advance the great army ('Ji' means urgent; the pronunciation is the reverse fanqie of Ji-Li).
translations.idiomatic: Yan You counseled Wang Yi: 'The city of Kunyang is small but well-fortified, and the pretender to the throne is currently in Wan. We should strike quickly with our main force ('Ji' signifies urgency; its pronunciation is indicated by the reverse fanqie of Ji-Li).'

sentences.zh: 宛敗，昆陽自服。」

translations.literal: Once Wan is defeated, Kunyang will submit on its own."
translations.idiomatic: Once Wan is subdued, Kunyang will have no choice but to surrender of its own accord.'

sentences.zh: 邑曰：「吾昔以虎牙將軍圍翟義，坐不生得，以見責讓。

translations.literal: Wang Yi said: "In the past, as Tiger's Teeth General, I besieged Zhai Yi; because I did not capture him alive, I was reprimanded and rebuked.
translations.idiomatic: Wang Yi replied: 'Years ago, when I was Tiger's Teeth General and besieged Zhai Yi, I was severely reprimanded because I failed to take him alive.'

sentences.zh: 〈翟義字文仲，方進少子，為東郡太守。

translations.literal: (Zhai Yi's courtesy name was Wenzhong; he was the youngest son of Zhai Fangjin and served as the Grand Administrator of Dongjun.)
translations.idiomatic: (Zhai Yi, courtesy name Wenzhong, was the youngest son of Zhai Fangjin and held the post of Grand Administrator of Dongjun.)

sentences.zh: 王莽居攝，義心惡之，乃立東平王雲子信為天子，義自號柱天大將軍，以誅莽。

translations.literal: When Wang Mang acted as regent, Yi hated him in his heart, so he established Liu Xin, the son of Prince Yun of Dongping, as the Son of Heaven; Yi called himself General-in-Chief Who Upholds Heaven to execute Mang.
translations.idiomatic: During the regency of Wang Mang, Zhai Yi harbored deep resentment toward him. He enthroned Liu Xin, the son of Prince Liu Yun of Dongping, as the Son of Heaven, and assumed the title of General-in-Chief Who Upholds Heaven to lead a campaign to eliminate Mang.

sentences.zh: 莽乃使孫建、王邑等將兵擊義，破之。

translations.literal: Mang then sent Sun Jian, Wang Yi, and others to lead troops to attack Yi, and they defeated him.
translations.idiomatic: Wang Mang dispatched Sun Jian, Wang Yi, and others with an army to crush Zhai Yi's rebellion, and they succeeded in defeating him.

sentences.zh: 義亡，自殺，故坐不生得。

translations.literal: Yi fled and committed suicide, thus he was not captured alive.
translations.idiomatic: Zhai Yi fled and eventually took his own life, which is why he was not taken alive.

sentences.zh: 坐音才卧反。

translations.literal: (The pronunciation of 'Zuo' is indicated by the reverse fanqie of Cai-Wo.)
translations.idiomatic: (The character 'Zuo' (convicted/on account of) is pronounced according to the reverse fanqie of Cai and Wo.)

sentences.zh: 見《前書》。〉今將百萬之衆，遇城而不能下，何謂邪？」

translations.literal: See the "Former Book".
translations.idiomatic: This is recorded in the Book of Han.

sentences.zh: 〈「遇」或為「過」。〉遂圍之數十重，列營百數，雲車十餘丈，〈雲車即樓車，稱雲，言其高也，升之以望敵，猶墨子云「公輸般為雲梯之械」。

translations.literal: ('Yu' (meet) is sometimes written as 'Guo' (pass).)
translations.idiomatic: (The character 'Yu' (to encounter) is sometimes replaced with 'Guo' (to pass).)

sentences.zh: 〈《說文》曰：「鉦，鐃也，似鈴。」〉或為地道，衝輣橦城。

translations.literal: (The "Shuowen" says: "'Zheng' is a bell-like instrument, similar to a 'Nao'.")
translations.idiomatic: (The 'Shuowen' dictionary defines the 'Zheng' as a bell-like percussion instrument, similar to the 'Nao'.)

sentences.zh: 〈衝，橦車也。

translations.literal: (Chong is a siege chariot.)
translations.idiomatic: (Chong refers to a siege chariot.)

sentences.zh: 詩曰：「臨衝閑閑。」

translations.literal: As in the poem: "Approaching the siege chariots leisurely."
translations.idiomatic: As the poem states: 'Approaching the siege chariots with leisurely grace.'

sentences.zh: 許慎曰：「輣，樓車也。」

translations.literal: Xu Shen said: "'Peng' is a tower chariot."
translations.idiomatic: Xu Shen explains: 'Peng refers to a tower chariot.'

sentences.zh: 輣音步耕反。〉積弩亂發，矢下如雨，城中負戶而汲。

translations.literal: (The pronunciation of 'Peng' is indicated by the reverse fanqie of Bu-Geng.)
translations.idiomatic: (The character 'Peng' is pronounced according to the reverse fanqie of Bu and Geng.)

sentences.zh: 王鳳等乞降，不許。

translations.literal: Wang Feng and others begged to surrender, but it was not permitted.
translations.idiomatic: Wang Feng and his companions pleaded for terms of surrender, but their request was denied.

sentences.zh: 尋、邑自以為功在漏刻，意氣甚逸。

translations.literal: Wang Xun and Wang Yi considered their success imminent within moments, their spirits extremely at ease.
translations.idiomatic: Wang Xun and Wang Yi were supremely confident, convinced that victory was mere moments away, their spirits soaring with complacency.

sentences.zh: 夜有流星墜營中，晝有雲如壞山，當營而隕，不及地尺而散，吏士皆厭伏。

translations.literal: At night a shooting star fell in the camp, and by day there was a cloud like a crumbling mountain that descended over the camp and dispersed before reaching a foot from the ground; the officers and soldiers all prostrated themselves in fear.
translations.idiomatic: At night, a meteor fell into their encampment; by day, a cloud resembling a collapsing mountain descended upon the camp but dissipated before touching the ground. Officers and soldiers alike prostrated themselves in terror.

sentences.zh: 〈《續漢志》曰：「雲如壞山，謂營頭之星也。

translations.literal: (The "Treatise of the Continued Book of Han" says: "A cloud like a crumbling mountain refers to the star over the camp.)
translations.idiomatic: (The 'Treatise of the Continued Book of Han' explains: 'A cloud resembling a crumbling mountain signifies the star that hangs over the camp.')

sentences.zh: 占曰：『營頭之所墜，其下覆軍殺將，血流千里。』」

translations.literal: The omen says: 'Where the star over the camp falls, the army below will be annihilated and the general killed, blood flowing a thousand li.'")
translations.idiomatic: The interpretation of this omen states: 'Where the star over the camp falls, the army beneath will be destroyed and the general slain, with blood flowing for a thousand li.'")

sentences.zh: 厭音一葉反。

translations.literal: (The pronunciation of 'Yan' is indicated by the reverse fanqie of Yi-Ye.)
translations.idiomatic: (The character 'Yan' is pronounced according to the reverse fanqie of Yi and Ye.)

sentences.zh: 六月己卯，光武遂與營部俱進，自將步騎千餘，前去大軍四五里而陳。

translations.literal: On the Ji Mao day of the sixth month, Guangwu then advanced together with his camp units; personally leading over a thousand infantry and cavalry, he went forward four or five li from the main army and formed battle lines.
translations.idiomatic: On the Ji Mao day of the sixth month, Guangwu led his entire contingent forward. Personally commanding more than a thousand infantry and cavalry, he advanced four or five li ahead of the main army and deployed into battle formation.

sentences.zh: 尋、邑亦遣兵數千合戰。

translations.literal: Wang Xun and Wang Yi also sent several thousand troops to join the battle.
translations.idiomatic: Wang Xun and Wang Yi dispatched several thousand troops to engage in the conflict.

sentences.zh: 光武奔之，斬首數十級。

translations.literal: Guangwu charged at them, beheading several dozen heads.
translations.idiomatic: Guangwu charged forward and personally beheaded several dozen enemy soldiers.

sentences.zh: 〈秦法，斬首一，賜爵一級，故因謂斬首為級。〉諸部喜曰：「劉將軍平生見小敵怯，今見大敵勇，甚可怪也，且復居前。

translations.literal: (By Qin law, for each head beheaded, one level of nobility was granted, thus they came to call beheading heads 'levels.')
translations.idiomatic: (Under Qin law, beheading one enemy earned a noble title of one level, which is why decapitating heads came to be called 'taking levels.')

sentences.zh: 請助將軍！」

translations.literal: Let us help the general!"
translations.idiomatic: Let us support General Liu!'

sentences.zh: 光武復進，尋、邑兵却，諸部共乘之，斬首數百千級。

translations.literal: Guangwu advanced again; Wang Xun and Wang Yi's troops retreated; the various units together pursued them, beheading several hundred thousand levels.
translations.idiomatic: Guangwu pressed the attack once more. Wang Xun and Wang Yi's forces retreated, and the various units pursued them together, claiming several hundred thousand enemy heads.

sentences.zh: 連勝，遂前。

translations.literal: They won repeatedly, and thus advanced.
translations.idiomatic: Victory followed victory, and they continued their advance.

sentences.zh: 時伯升拔宛已三日，而光武尚未知，乃偽使持書報城中，云「宛下兵到」，而陽墯其書。

translations.literal: At this time, Bosheng had already captured Wan three days earlier, but Guangwu did not yet know; he falsely sent a messenger carrying a letter to report to the city, saying "The troops from below Wan have arrived," and intentionally dropped the letter.
translations.idiomatic: At this moment, Liu Bosheng had already captured Wan three days earlier, though Guangwu was unaware of this. Guangwu sent a false messenger with a letter to the besieged city claiming 'Reinforcements from below Wan have arrived,' and deliberately let the letter fall where the enemy could find it.

sentences.zh: 尋、邑得之，不憙。

translations.literal: Wang Xun and Wang Yi obtained it, and were not pleased.
translations.idiomatic: Wang Xun and Wang Yi discovered the letter, and their spirits sank.

sentences.zh: 〈憙音許記反。〉諸將旣經累捷，膽氣益壯，無不一當百。

translations.literal: (The pronunciation of 'Xi' is indicated by the reverse fanqie of Xu-Ji.)
translations.idiomatic: (The character 'Xi' is pronounced according to the reverse fanqie of Xu and Ji.)

sentences.zh: 光武乃與敢死者三千人，從城西水上衝其中堅，〈敢死謂果敢而死者。

translations.literal: Guangwu then, with three thousand who dared to die, charged from the west of the city along the water against their central stronghold. (Those who dared to die means those who were determined and would die.)
translations.idiomatic: Guangwu then led three thousand desperate volunteers in a charge from the city's west side along the watercourse, directly assaulting the enemy's central command. (The 'dare-to-die' warriors were those who fought with reckless determination, prepared to sacrifice their lives.)

sentences.zh: 凡軍事，中軍將最尊，居中以堅銳自輔，故曰中堅也。〉尋、邑陳亂，乘銳崩之，遂殺王尋。

translations.literal: In all military affairs, the central army general is most honored, residing in the center to support himself with the strongest and sharpest forces, thus it is called the central stronghold.)
translations.idiomatic: In military operations, the commander of the central army holds the highest position, stationed in the center and protected by the finest and most elite troops, which is why it is called the 'central stronghold' or backbone of the army.)

sentences.zh: 城中亦鼓譟而出，中外合埶，震呼動天地，莽兵大潰，走者相騰踐，奔殪百餘里閒。

translations.literal: The city also beat drums and shouted as they emerged; inside and outside combined their forces, their shouts shook heaven and earth; Wang Mang's troops greatly collapsed; the fleeing ones trampled each other, and they ran and died over a hundred li.
translations.idiomatic: The defenders within Kunyang also emerged with drums beating and battle cries resounding. With forces coordinating from inside and outside, their shouts shook heaven and earth. Wang Mang's army collapsed in utter rout, with fleeing soldiers trampling each other underfoot as they perished in panicked flight for over a hundred li.

sentences.zh: 〈殪，仆也，音於計反。

translations.literal: ('Yi' means to fall down; the pronunciation is the reverse fanqie of Yu-Ji.)
translations.idiomatic: (The character 'Yi' means to fall or collapse; its pronunciation is indicated by the reverse fanqie of Yu and Ji.)

sentences.zh: 或作「噎」。〉會大雷風，屋瓦皆飛，雨下如注，滍川盛溢，〈水經曰，滍水出南陽魯陽縣西堯山，東南經昆陽城北，東入汝。

translations.literal: Sometimes it is written as 'Ye'.
translations.idiomatic: The character is sometimes written as 'Ye' (choke).

sentences.zh: 滍音直理反。〉虎豹皆股戰，士卒爭赴，溺死者以萬數，水為不流。

translations.literal: (The pronunciation of 'Chan' is indicated by the reverse fanqie of Zhi-Li.)
translations.idiomatic: (The character 'Chan' is pronounced according to the reverse fanqie of Zhi and Li.)

sentences.zh: 〈數過於萬，故以萬為數。〉王邑、嚴尤、陳茂輕騎乘死人度水逃去。

translations.literal: (The number exceeded ten thousand, thus they use ten thousand as the count.)
translations.idiomatic: (The casualties exceeded ten thousand, so the number is given as 'tens of thousands' as an approximation.)

sentences.zh: 盡獲其軍實輜重，車甲珍寶，不可勝筭，舉之連月不盡，或燔燒其餘。

translations.literal: They completely obtained their military supplies and baggage, chariots and armor, precious treasures, which could not be counted; carrying them away took months without end; some burned the remainder.
translations.idiomatic: They captured the enemy's entire arsenal of military supplies and heavy baggage, along with chariots, armor, and priceless treasures beyond counting. It took months to transport all the spoils, and what remained was set ablaze.

sentences.zh: 光武因復徇下潁陽。

translations.literal: Guangwu then again made a circuitous tour and brought Yingyang under submission.
translations.idiomatic: Guangwu then continued his campaign, bringing Yingyang under his control through a display of force.

sentences.zh: 〈縣名，屬潁川郡，故城在今許州。〉會伯升為更始所害，光武自父城馳詣宛謝。

translations.literal: (County name, belonging to Yingchuan Commandery; the ancient city is in modern Xuzhou.)
translations.idiomatic: (Yingyang was a county under Yingchuan Commandery; its ancient administrative seat corresponds to modern Xuzhou.)

sentences.zh: 〈父城，縣，古應國也，屬潁川郡，故城在今許州葉縣東北。

translations.literal: (Fucheng was a county, the ancient state of Ying, belonging to Yingchuan Commandery; the ancient city is northeast of Ye County in modern Xuzhou.)
translations.idiomatic: (Fucheng was a county and the site of the ancient state of Ying, under Yingchuan Commandery; its ancient administrative center lay northeast of Ye County in modern Xuzhou.)

sentences.zh: 以伯升見害，心不自安，故謝。〉司徒官屬迎弔光武，光武難交私語，深引過而已。

translations.literal: Because Bosheng was harmed, his heart was not at peace, thus he apologized.
translations.idiomatic: Disturbed by his brother's assassination and fearing for his own safety, Guangwu offered his formal apology.

sentences.zh: 未甞自伐昆陽之功，又不敢為伯升服喪，飲食言笑如平常。

translations.literal: He never boasted of the merit of Kunyang, and moreover did not dare to observe mourning for Bosheng, eating, drinking, speaking, and laughing as usual.
translations.idiomatic: He never boasted of his victory at Kunyang, nor did he dare observe formal mourning for his brother Bosheng. He continued eating, drinking, speaking, and laughing as if nothing had changed.

sentences.zh: 更始以是慙，拜光武為破虜大將軍，封武信侯。

translations.literal: Gengshi was ashamed by this, and appointed Guangwu as Great General Who Breaks the Barbarians, enfeoffing him as Marquis of Wuxin.
translations.idiomatic: The Gengshi Emperor, feeling embarrassed by Guangwu's humility, appointed him Great General Who Breaks the Barbarians and enfeoffed him as Marquis of Wuxin.

sentences.zh: 九月庚戌，三輔豪桀共誅王莽，傳首詣宛。

translations.literal: On the Gengxu day of the ninth month, the heroic and outstanding men of the Three Fu together executed Wang Mang and transmitted his head to Wan.
translations.idiomatic: On the Gengxu day of the ninth month, the bold leaders and heroes of the Three Fu regions united to execute Wang Mang and sent his head to Wan.

sentences.zh: 〈三輔謂京兆、左馮翊、右扶風，共在長安中，分領諸縣。

translations.literal: (The Three Fu refer to Jingzhao, Zuo Fengyi, and You Fufeng; they were all within Chang'an, each administering various counties.)
translations.idiomatic: (The Three Fu regions consisted of Jingzhao, Zuo Fengyi, and You Fufeng—all administrative divisions centered around Chang'an, each overseeing multiple counties.)

sentences.zh: 淮南子曰：「智過百人謂之豪。」

translations.literal: The "Huainanzi" says: "One whose wisdom surpasses a hundred men is called a hero."
translations.idiomatic: The Huainanzi states: 'A man whose wisdom exceeds that of a hundred others is called a hero (hao).'

sentences.zh: 白虎通云：「賢萬人曰傑。」

translations.literal: The "White Tiger Hall Discussions" says: "One who is worthy above ten thousand men is called outstanding."
translations.idiomatic: The White Tiger Hall Discussions define: 'One who excels among ten thousand is called outstanding (jie).'

sentences.zh: 時城中少年子弟張魚等攻莽於漸臺，商人杜吳殺莽，校尉公賔就斬莽首，將軍申屠建等傳莽首詣宛。

translations.literal: At that time, young men in the city including Zhang Yu and others attacked Mang at the Jian Terrace; the merchant Du Wu killed Mang; Colonel Gong Bin You cut off Mang's head; General Shen Tu Jian and others transmitted Mang's head to Wan.
translations.idiomatic: At the time, young men in the city including Zhang Yu attacked Wang Mang at the Jian Terrace. The merchant Du Wu assassinated him, Colonel Gong Bin You severed his head, and General Shen Tu Jian and others delivered it to Wan.

sentences.zh: 更始將北都洛陽，以光武行司隷校尉，使前整修宮府。

translations.literal: Gengshi was about to make Luoyang his northern capital, and appointed Guangwu as acting Commandant of the Capital Region, sending him ahead to repair and maintain the palaces and offices.
translations.idiomatic: The Gengshi Emperor planned to establish Luoyang as his northern capital. He appointed Guangwu as acting Commandant of the Capital Region and sent him ahead to restore the imperial palaces and government offices.

sentences.zh: 〈《前書》曰：司隷校尉本周官，武帝初置，持節，從中都官徒千二百人，督大姦猾。

translations.literal: (The "Former Book" says: The Commandant of the Capital Region was originally a Zhou office; Emperor Wu initially established it; he held the tally, with 1,200 convicts from the central capital offices, supervising great villains and evildoers.)
translations.idiomatic: (The Book of Han notes that the office of Commandant of the Capital Region originated as a Zhou dynasty position. Emperor Wu first established it in the Han dynasty, granting its holder a ceremonial tally and 1,200 convict laborers from the central government offices to oversee major criminals and corrupt officials.)

sentences.zh: 後罷其兵，察三輔、三河、弘農。

translations.literal: Later they abolished its troops, and it oversaw the Three Fu, Three Rivers, and Hongnong.
translations.idiomatic: Later, the office's military forces were disbanded, and it was tasked with overseeing the Three Fu regions, the Three Rivers area, and Hongnong.

sentences.zh: 秩比二千石。

translations.literal: The rank was equivalent to 2,000 piculs.
translations.idiomatic: The office carried a rank and salary equivalent to 2,000 piculs of grain.

sentences.zh: 音義云：「以掌徒隷而巡察，故曰司隷。」〉於是置僚屬，作文移，〈《東觀記》曰「文書移與屬縣」也。

translations.literal: The Phonetics and Meanings says: "Because it controls convicts and makes inspections, it is thus called Commandant of the Capital Region."
translations.idiomatic: The Phonetics and Meanings commentary explains: 'Since it oversees convict labor and conducts inspections, it is called the Commandant of the Capital Region (Si Li).'

sentences.zh: 〈《續漢書》曰：「司隷置從事史十二人，秩皆百石，主督促文書，察舉非法。」〉時三輔吏士東迎更始，見諸將過，皆冠幘，〈漢官儀曰：「幘者，古之卑賤不冠者之所服也。」

translations.literal: (The "Continued Book of Han" says: "The Commandant of the Capital Region established twelve Attendant Officials, all ranking at 100 piculs, in charge of urging official documents and investigating and recommending illegal acts.")
translations.idiomatic: (The 'Continued Book of Han' records: 'The office of Commandant of the Capital Region employed twelve Attendant Officials, each with a rank of 100 piculs. They were responsible for expediting official documents and investigating misconduct to recommend appropriate actions.')

sentences.zh: 方言曰：「覆髻謂之幘，或謂之承露。」〉而服婦人衣，諸于繡镼，〈《前書》音義曰：「諸于，大掖衣也，如婦人之褂衣。」

translations.literal: The "Fangyan" says: "A wrapped topknot is called a 'ze', or sometimes called 'receiving dew'."
translations.idiomatic: The Fangyan dictionary states: 'A head covering that wraps around the topknot is called a ze, or sometimes referred to as a "dew receiver."'

sentences.zh: 字書無「镼」字，續漢書作「䘿」，並音其物反。

translations.literal: The character books have no "xiu" character; the Continued Book of Han writes it as "chang", both pronounced as the reverse fanqie of qi-wu.)
translations.idiomatic: The character dictionaries contain no entry for '镼'; the Continued Book of Han uses '䘿' instead, both pronounced according to the reverse fanqie of qi-wu.)

sentences.zh: 楊雄方言曰：「襜褕，其短者，自關之西謂之『䘪䘿』。」

translations.literal: Yang Xiong's "Fangyan" says: "For the changyu garment, its short version, west of the pass is called 'changchang'."
translations.idiomatic: Yang Xiong's Fangyan states: 'For the changyu garment, the shorter version is called "changchang" in the regions west of the pass.'

sentences.zh: 郭璞注云：「俗名䘿掖。」

translations.literal: Guo Pu's commentary says: "The common name is 'changye'."
translations.idiomatic: Guo Pu's annotation notes: 'It is commonly known as changye.'

sentences.zh: 據此，即是諸于上加繡䘿，如今之半臂也。

translations.literal: Based on this, it is a zhuyu garment with embroidered chang added, like today's half-sleeves.)
translations.idiomatic: From this, it appears to be a zhuyu garment with an embroidered chang overlay, similar to modern half-sleeves.)

sentences.zh: 或「繡」下有「擁」字。〉莫不笑之，或有畏而走者。

translations.literal: Sometimes there is a "yong" character below "xiu".
translations.idiomatic: In some versions, there is an additional '拥' (yong) character after '绣' (xiu).

sentences.zh: 〈《續漢志》曰：「時知者見之，以為服之不中，身之災也，乃奔入邊郡避之。

translations.literal: (The "Treatise of the Continued Book of Han" says: "At that time, those who understood saw it and considered it improper clothing, a disaster for the body, so they fled to the border commanderies to avoid it.
translations.idiomatic: (The 'Treatise of the Continued Book of Han' records: 'Wise observers at the time viewed this as inappropriate attire that would bring disaster upon its wearers. Many fled to the border commanderies to escape the impending catastrophe.

sentences.zh: 是服妖也。

translations.literal: This is a clothing anomaly.)
translations.idiomatic: This was an omen manifested in clothing.)

sentences.zh: 其後更始遂為赤眉所殺。」〉及見司隷僚屬，皆歡喜不自勝。

translations.literal: Afterward, Gengshi was ultimately killed by the Red Eyebrows.")
translations.idiomatic: Subsequently, the Gengshi Emperor was assassinated by the Red Eyebrow rebels.")

sentences.zh: 老吏或垂涕曰：「不圖今日復見漢官威儀！」

translations.literal: Some old officials wept and said: "We never imagined that today we would again see the dignity and ceremony of Han officials!"
translations.idiomatic: Veteran officials shed tears, exclaiming, 'We never dreamed we would live to see the majesty and proper ceremonies of Han officialdom once more!'

sentences.zh: 由是識者皆屬心焉。

translations.literal: From this, those who understood all devoted their hearts to him.
translations.idiomatic: From that moment, all discerning observers pledged their loyalty to Guangwu.

sentences.zh: 及更始至洛陽，乃遣光武以破虜將軍行大司馬事。

translations.literal: When Gengshi arrived at Luoyang, he sent Guangwu as Great General Who Breaks the Barbarians to act as Grand Marshal.
translations.idiomatic: Upon the Gengshi Emperor's arrival in Luoyang, he dispatched Guangwu as Great General Who Breaks the Barbarians to serve as acting Grand Marshal.

sentences.zh: 十月，持節北度河，〈漢官儀曰：「太尉，秦官也，武帝更名大司馬。」

translations.literal: In the tenth month, holding the tally, he crossed the river to the north. (The "Apparatus of Han Officials" says: "The Grand Commandant was a Qin office; Emperor Wu changed the name to Grand Marshal.")
translations.idiomatic: In the tenth month, bearing his imperial tally, Guangwu crossed north over the Yellow River. (According to the 'Apparatus of Han Officials': 'The office of Grand Commandant originated in the Qin dynasty; Emperor Wu renamed it Grand Marshal.')

sentences.zh: 節，所以為信也，以竹為之，柄長八尺，以旄牛尾為其眊三重。

translations.literal: The tally was what served as proof of authority; it was made of bamboo, with a handle eight feet long, using yak tails to make its tassels in three layers.
translations.idiomatic: The imperial tally served as proof of authority; crafted from bamboo with an eight-foot handle, its tassels were made from yak tails in three layers.

sentences.zh: 馮衍與田邑書曰：「今以一節之任，建三軍之威，豈特寵其八尺之竹，犛牛之尾哉！」

translations.literal: Feng Yan, in his letter to Tian Yi, said: "Now with the responsibility of one tally, he establishes the awe of the three armies—how is it merely honoring the eight-foot bamboo and yak tail?!"
translations.idiomatic: Feng Yan wrote in a letter to Tian Yi: 'Now entrusted with a single imperial tally, he commands the awe of three armies—surely this is more than mere honor paid to an eight-foot bamboo staff and yak-tail tassels!'

sentences.zh: 《續漢志》曰：「更始時，南方有童謠云：『諧不諧，在赤眉；

translations.literal: The "Treatise of the Continued Book of Han" says: "During Gengshi's time, there was a children's rhyme in the south that went: 'Harmony or no harmony lies with the Red Eyebrows;
translations.idiomatic: The 'Treatise of the Continued Book of Han' records: 'During the Gengshi emperor's reign, a children's rhyme circulated in the south: "Will there be harmony or not? It lies with the Red Eyebrows;"

sentences.zh: 得不得，在河北。』

translations.literal: Success or failure lies north of the river."
translations.idiomatic: Success or failure depends on what happens north of the river."'

sentences.zh: 後更始為赤眉所殺，是不諧也；

translations.literal: Later, Gengshi was killed by the Red Eyebrows—this was the lack of harmony;
translations.idiomatic: Later, the Gengshi emperor was assassinated by the Red Eyebrow rebels—this represented the lack of harmony;

sentences.zh: 光武由河北而興，是得之也。」〉鎮慰州郡。

translations.literal: Guangwu rose from north of the river—this was the success."
translations.idiomatic: Guangwu rose to power from the region north of the river—this signified the success."

sentences.zh: 所到部縣，輒見二千石、長吏、三老、官屬，下至佐史，〈二千百謂郡守也。

translations.literal: In every commandery and county he reached, he would meet with the officials of 2,000 piculs rank, senior officials, the Three Elders, and subordinate officials, down to the assistants and clerks. (The 2,000 piculs refers to the Grand Administrators.)
translations.idiomatic: In every commandery and county he visited, Guangwu would meet with officials ranked at 2,000 piculs, senior administrators, the Three Elders, and subordinate staff, down to the lowest assistants and scribes. (Officials of 2,000 piculs referred to the Grand Administrators.)

sentences.zh: 長吏謂縣令長及丞尉也。

translations.literal: Senior officials refer to county magistrates, chiefs, and their deputies and commandants.
translations.idiomatic: Senior administrators included county magistrates, chiefs, and their deputies and commandants.

sentences.zh: 三老者，郷官也。

translations.literal: The Three Elders were township officials.
translations.idiomatic: The Three Elders were local township officials.

sentences.zh: 高祖置。

translations.literal: Established by Gaozu.
translations.idiomatic: This office was established by Emperor Gaozu.

sentences.zh: 《前書》曰：「舉人年五十已上，有修行能帥衆者，置以為三老，每郷一人；

translations.literal: The "Former Book" says: "Select men aged fifty and above who have cultivated virtue and can lead the masses, appoint them as Three Elders, one per township;
translations.idiomatic: The Book of Han states: 'Select men aged fifty or older who have cultivated moral character and can lead the people; appoint them as Three Elders, one per township;'

sentences.zh: 擇郷三老為縣三老，與令長丞尉以事相敎，復其傜戍。」

translations.literal: select the township Three Elders to be county Three Elders, who together with the magistrates, chiefs, deputies, and commandants teach each other in matters, and exempt them from labor service and garrison duty."
translations.idiomatic: select township Three Elders to serve as county Three Elders, who collaborate with magistrates, chiefs, deputies, and commandants in teaching and guiding affairs, and exempt them from corvee labor and military service."

sentences.zh: 《續漢志》曰「每刺史皆有從事史、假佐，每縣各置諸事曹史」也。〉考察黜陟，如州牧行部事。

translations.literal: The "Treatise of the Continued Book of Han" says "each Inspector has Attendant Officials and Acting Assistants; each county establishes various affairs section scribes".
translations.idiomatic: The 'Treatise of the Continued Book of Han' notes that 'each Inspector is assigned Attendant Officials and Acting Assistants; each county establishes scribes for the various administrative sections.'

sentences.zh: 〈漢初遣丞相史分刺州，武帝改置刺史，察州，秩六百石。

translations.literal: (In the early Han, Chancellor secretaries were sent to inspect the provinces separately; Emperor Wu changed it to establish Inspectors who oversaw provinces, with a rank of 600 piculs.)
translations.idiomatic: (In the early Han dynasty, secretaries from the Chancellor's office were dispatched to inspect individual provinces; Emperor Wu reorganized this by establishing the office of Inspector to oversee provincial affairs, with a rank of 600 piculs.)

sentences.zh: 成帝更名牧，秩二千石。

translations.literal: Emperor Cheng changed the name to Governor, with a rank of 2,000 piculs.)
translations.idiomatic: During Emperor Cheng's reign, the title was changed to Governor, carrying a rank of 2,000 piculs.)

sentences.zh: 漢官典儀曰「刺史行郡國，省察政敎，黜陟能不，斷理冤獄」也。〉輒平遣囚徒，除王莽苛政，〈《說文》曰：「苛，小草也。」

translations.literal: The "Standard Rites of Han Officials" says "the Inspector tours the commanderies and kingdoms, inspects and examines government and education, demotes or promotes the capable and incapable, and adjudicates and settles unjust cases".
translations.idiomatic: The 'Standard Rites of Han Officials' describes the Inspector's duties as touring commanderies and kingdoms, inspecting governance and education, promoting the capable and demoting the incompetent, and adjudicating wrongful legal cases.

sentences.zh: 言政令繁細。

translations.literal: It means the government orders were numerous and detailed.)
translations.idiomatic: This refers to government decrees that were excessively detailed and burdensome.)

sentences.zh: 禮記曰：「苛政猛於虎。」〉復漢官名。

translations.literal: The "Book of Rites" says: "Harsh government is fiercer than a tiger."
translations.idiomatic: As the Book of Rites states: 'Oppressive governance is more ferocious than a tiger.'

sentences.zh: 吏人喜恱，爭持牛酒迎勞。

translations.literal: The officials and people were delighted, and competed to bring oxen and wine to welcome and console him.
translations.idiomatic: Officials and common people alike were overjoyed, vying to bring oxen and wine to welcome and honor Guangwu.

sentences.zh: 進至邯鄲，〈縣名，屬趙國，今洺州縣也。

translations.literal: He advanced to Handan. (County name, belonging to Zhao kingdom, now Mingzhou county.)
translations.idiomatic: He advanced to Handan. (This county belonged to the Zhao kingdom and corresponds to modern Mingzhou.)

sentences.zh: 《前書》音義：「邯，山名；

translations.literal: The "Book of Han" Phonetics and Meanings: "'Han' is a mountain name;
translations.idiomatic: The 'Phonetics and Meanings of the Book of Han' explains: 'Han refers to a mountain name;'

sentences.zh: 鄲，盡也。

translations.literal: 'Dan' means to exhaust.
translations.idiomatic: 'Dan' signifies completion or exhaustion.

sentences.zh: 邯山至此而盡。

translations.literal: Mount Han comes to an end here.
translations.idiomatic: Mount Han terminates at this location.

sentences.zh: 城郭字皆從邑，因以名焉。」〉故趙繆王子林〈繆王，景帝七代孫，名元。

translations.literal: The characters for city walls all contain the 'town' radical, and thus it was named accordingly."
translations.idiomatic: All characters for walled cities include the 'town' radical (yi), which explains the origin of the name."

sentences.zh: 《前書》曰，元坐殺人，為大鴻臚所奏。

translations.literal: The "Former Book" says that Yuan was convicted of murder and was impeached by the Grand Herald.)
translations.idiomatic: The Book of Han records that Liu Yuan was convicted of murder and impeached by the Grand Herald.)

sentences.zh: 謚曰繆，音謬。

translations.literal: His posthumous title was Mu, pronounced Miu.)
translations.idiomatic: He was posthumously titled Mu, which is pronounced Miu.)

sentences.zh: 《東觀記》曰「林」作「臨」字。〉說光武曰：「赤眉今在河東，但決水灌之，百萬之衆可使為魚。」

translations.literal: The "Records of the Eastern Pavilion" says that "Lin" is written as the character "Lin".)
translations.idiomatic: The 'Records of the Eastern Pavilion' notes that the character for Lin is sometimes written as Lin.)

sentences.zh: 〈赤眉賊帥樊崇等恐其衆與王莽兵亂，皆朱其眉以相別，故曰赤眉。

translations.literal: (The Red Eyebrow bandit leader Fan Chong and others, fearing that their followers would mix with Wang Mang's troops in confusion, all painted their eyebrows red to distinguish themselves, thus they were called the Red Eyebrows.)
translations.idiomatic: (The Red Eyebrow rebel leader Fan Chong and his followers, fearing their troops would become indistinguishable from Wang Mang's forces, painted their eyebrows red as a distinguishing mark, which is how they earned the name 'Red Eyebrows.')

sentences.zh: 《續漢書》曰：「是時上平河北，過邯鄲，林進見，言赤眉可破。

translations.literal: The "Continued Book of Han" says: "At this time, the Emperor had pacified the area north of the Yellow River; passing through Handan, Lin came forward to meet him and said the Red Eyebrows could be defeated.
translations.idiomatic: The 'Continued Book of Han' records: 'At this time, the future Emperor Guangwu had pacified the region north of the Yellow River. Passing through Handan, Liu Lin approached him and claimed that the Red Eyebrow forces could be defeated.'

sentences.zh: 上問其故，對曰：『河水從列人北流；

translations.literal: The Emperor asked the reason, and he replied: 'The river water flows north from Lieren;
translations.idiomatic: Guangwu inquired about the reasoning, and Liu Lin replied: 'The river water flows northward from Lieren;'

sentences.zh: 如決河水灌之，皆可令為魚。』

translations.literal: if we breach the river and flood them with water, we can all turn them into fish.'")
translations.idiomatic: if we breach the dikes and flood them, we can turn their entire army into fish.'")

sentences.zh: 上不然之。」

translations.literal: The Emperor did not agree with this.")
translations.idiomatic: Guangwu rejected this proposal.")

sentences.zh: 列人，縣，故城在今洺州肥郷縣東北。〉光武不荅，去之真定。

translations.literal: Lieren was a county; its ancient city is northeast of modern Feixiang County in Mingzhou.)
translations.idiomatic: Lieren was a county whose ancient administrative seat lay northeast of present-day Feixiang in Mingzhou.)

sentences.zh: 〈縣名，屬真定國，今恒州縣也。〉林於是乃詐以卜者王郎為成帝子子輿，〈《前書》曰，立國將軍孫建奏云「不知何一男子遮臣車前，自稱漢氏劉子輿，成帝下妻子也，劉氏當復」。

translations.literal: (County name, belonging to Zhending kingdom, now Hengzhou county.)
translations.idiomatic: (Zhending was a county within the Zhending kingdom, corresponding to modern Hengzhou.)

sentences.zh: 故郎因而稱之。〉十二月，立郎為天子，都邯鄲，遂遣使者降下郡國。

translations.literal: Therefore Lang adopted this claim.)
translations.idiomatic: Wang Lang therefore appropriated this identity.)

sentences.zh: 二年正月，光武以王郎新盛，乃北徇薊。

translations.literal: In the first month of the second year, Guangwu, seeing that Wang Lang was newly powerful, then made a tour of inspection northward to Ji.
translations.idiomatic: In the first month of the second year, Guangwu, recognizing that Wang Lang's power was newly ascendant, conducted a campaign northward toward Ji.

sentences.zh: 〈縣名，屬涿郡，今幽州縣也。

translations.literal: (County name, belonging to Zhuojun Commandery, now Youzhou county.)
translations.idiomatic: (Ji was a county within Zhuojun Commandery, corresponding to modern Youzhou.)

sentences.zh: 本字從「契」從「邑」，見說文。〉王郎移檄購光武十萬戶，〈《說文》曰：「檄，以木簡為書，長尺二寸。

translations.literal: The original character is composed of 'qi' and 'town'; see the Shuowen.)
translations.idiomatic: The original character combines the radicals for 'qi' and 'town'; this is documented in the Shuowen dictionary.)

sentences.zh: 謂之檄，以徵召也。」

translations.literal: It is called xi because it summons and calls.")
translations.idiomatic: Such documents are called xi because they are used for summoning and calling forth.")

sentences.zh: 又曰：「以財有所求曰購。」

translations.literal: It also says: "To seek something with wealth is called gou.")
translations.idiomatic: The dictionary further states: 'To offer wealth in pursuit of something is called gou.")

sentences.zh: 魏武奏事曰：「若有急，即插以雞羽，謂之羽檄。」〉而故廣陽王子劉接〈廣陽王名嘉，武帝五代孫。

translations.literal: Wei Wu's memorial said: "If there is urgency, insert chicken feathers, and it is called a feathered xi.")
translations.idiomatic: Cao Cao's memorial stated: 'In cases of extreme urgency, attach chicken feathers to the document, which is then called a feathered xi.")

sentences.zh: 於是光武趣駕南轅，〈趣，急也，讀曰促。〉晨夜不敢入城邑，舍食道傍。

translations.literal: Thereupon Guangwu urged his carriage southward. (Qu means urgent; read as cu.)
translations.idiomatic: Guangwu therefore urged his carriage southward in haste. (The character 'qu' signifies urgency and is read as 'cu.')

sentences.zh: 至饒陽，〈縣名，屬安平國，在饒河之陽，故城在今瀛州饒陽縣東北。〉官屬皆乏食。

translations.literal: He reached Raoyang. (County name, belonging to Anping kingdom, on the north bank of the Rao River; the ancient city is northeast of modern Raoyang County in Yingzhou.)
translations.idiomatic: He reached Raoyang. (This county belonged to the Anping kingdom and was situated on the north bank of the Rao River; its ancient administrative seat lay northeast of present-day Raoyang in Yingzhou.)

sentences.zh: 光武乃自稱邯鄲使者，入傳舍。

translations.literal: Guangwu then called himself an envoy from Handan and entered the relay station.
translations.idiomatic: Guangwu disguised himself as an envoy from Handan and entered the official relay station.

sentences.zh: 〈客館也。

translations.literal: (A guest lodge.)
translations.idiomatic: (A lodging for travelers and officials.)

sentences.zh: 傳音知戀反，下同。〉傳吏方進食，從者飢，爭奪之。

translations.literal: (Zhuan is pronounced as the reverse fanqie of zhi-lian; same below.)
translations.idiomatic: (The character 'zhuan' is pronounced according to the reverse fanqie of zhi and lian; this applies below as well.)

sentences.zh: 傳吏疑其偽，乃椎鼓數十通，〈椎音直追反。〉紿言邯鄲將軍至，〈紿，言欺誑也，音殆。

translations.literal: The relay station official suspected deception, so he beat the drum dozens of times. (Chui is pronounced as the reverse fanqie of zhi-zhui.)
translations.idiomatic: The relay station official grew suspicious of their deception and beat the alarm drum dozens of times. (The character 'chui' is pronounced according to the reverse fanqie of zhi and zhui.)

sentences.zh: 光武升車欲馳；

translations.literal: Guangwu mounted his carriage and wanted to gallop away;
translations.idiomatic: Guangwu leaped into his carriage, ready to flee at full speed;

sentences.zh: 旣而懼不免，徐還坐，曰：「請邯鄲將軍入。」

translations.literal: but then fearing he could not escape, he slowly returned to his seat and said: "Please let the Handan general enter."
translations.idiomatic: but then, fearing escape was impossible, he slowly returned to his seat and calmly said, 'Please show the general from Handan in.'

sentences.zh: 乆乃駕去。

translations.literal: After a long time, he drove away.
translations.idiomatic: Only after a considerable delay did he depart.

sentences.zh: 傳中人遙語門者閉之。

translations.literal: Someone in the relay station called out from afar to the gatekeeper to close it.
translations.idiomatic: From within the relay station, someone shouted to the gatekeeper to shut the gates.

sentences.zh: 門長曰：「天下詎可知，而閉長者乎？」

translations.literal: The gate chief said: "How can one know about the world, and close the gates on an elder?"
translations.idiomatic: The gatekeeper replied: 'In these uncertain times, how can we be sure? But surely we shouldn't bar the way to an honorable elder!'

sentences.zh: 遂得南出。

translations.literal: Thus they were able to go out southward.
translations.idiomatic: They were thus able to escape southward.

sentences.zh: 晨夜兼行，蒙犯霜雪，〈蒙，冒也。〉天時寒，面皆破裂。

translations.literal: They traveled both day and night, braving frost and snow. (Meng means to face.)
translations.idiomatic: They journeyed day and night through bitter cold, enduring frost and snow. (The character 'meng' means to confront or brave.)

sentences.zh: 至呼沱河，〈《山海經》云：「太戲之山，滹沱之水出焉。」

translations.literal: They reached the Hutuo River. (The "Classic of Mountains and Seas" says: "From Mount Taixi, the waters of the Hutuo emerge.")
translations.idiomatic: They reached the Hutuo River. (The 'Classic of Mountains and Seas' states: 'The Hutuo waters flow forth from Mount Taixi.')

sentences.zh: 在今代州繁畤縣東，流經定州深澤縣東南，即光武所度處，今俗猶謂之危度口。

translations.literal: It is east of modern Fanzhi County in Daizhou, flows southeast through Shenze County in Dingzhou—that is the place where Guangwu crossed; today the common people still call it the Perilous Crossing Mouth.
translations.idiomatic: The river lies east of present-day Fanzhi in Daizhou and flows southeast through Shenze in Dingzhou—this was precisely where Guangwu made his crossing, and locals still refer to it as the Dangerous Ford.

sentences.zh: 臣賢案：呼沱河舊在饒陽南，至魏太祖曹操因饒河故瀆決，令北注新溝水，所以今在饒陽縣北。〉無船，適遇冰合，得過，〈《續漢書》曰：「時冰滑馬僵，乃各以囊盛沙，布冰上度焉。」

translations.literal: Chen Xian's commentary: The Hutuo River was formerly south of Raoyang; when Wei Taizu Cao Cao caused the old channel of the Rao River to burst, he had the waters flow north into a new ditch, which is why it is now north of Raoyang County.
translations.idiomatic: Chen Xian notes: The Hutuo River originally flowed south of Raoyang. When Cao Cao, the Wei Taizu, breached the old Rao River channel, he diverted the waters northward through a new canal, which explains why it now lies north of Raoyang County.

sentences.zh: 進至下博城西，〈下博，縣，屬信都國。

translations.literal: They advanced to west of Xiabo city. (Xiabo was a county belonging to Xindu kingdom.)
translations.idiomatic: They advanced to the west of Xiabo city. (Xiabo was a county under the jurisdiction of Xindu kingdom.)

sentences.zh: 在博水之下，故曰下博。

translations.literal: It was below the Bo River, thus called Xiabo.
translations.idiomatic: Situated downstream from the Bo River, it was therefore named Xiabo (Lower Bo).

sentences.zh: 故城在今兾州下博縣南。〉遑惑不知所之。

translations.literal: The ancient city is south of modern Xiabo County in Jizhou.
translations.idiomatic: The ancient administrative seat lies south of present-day Xiabo in Jizhou.

sentences.zh: 有白衣老父在道旁，〈老父蓋神人也，今下博縣西猶有祠堂。〉指曰：「努力！

translations.literal: There was a white-robed old man by the roadside. (The old man was probably a divine being; today west of Xiabo County there is still a shrine.)
translations.idiomatic: An old man dressed in white stood by the roadside. (This elder was likely a divine figure; even today, a shrine dedicated to him stands west of Xiabo County.)

sentences.zh: 信都郡為長安守，去此八十里。」

translations.literal: Xindu Commandery is guarding Chang'an; it is eighty li from here."
translations.idiomatic: The Xindu Commandery stands as a bulwark protecting Chang'an; it lies just eighty li from this spot.'

sentences.zh: 〈信都郡，今兾州也。〉光武即馳赴之，信都太守任光開門出迎。

translations.literal: (Xindu Commandery is modern Jizhou.)
translations.idiomatic: (Xindu Commandery corresponds to modern Jizhou.)

sentences.zh: 世祖因發旁縣，得四千人，先擊堂陽、貰縣，皆降之。

translations.literal: Shizu then mobilized the neighboring counties and obtained four thousand men; he first attacked Tangyang and Shi County, and they all surrendered.
translations.idiomatic: Guangwu then called up troops from the surrounding counties, gathering four thousand men. He launched his first attacks against Tangyang and Shi County, both of which surrendered to him.

sentences.zh: 〈堂陽及貰並屬鉅鹿郡。

translations.literal: (Tongyang and Shi both belonged to Julu Commandery.)
translations.idiomatic: (Both Tangyang and Shi County were under the jurisdiction of Julu Commandery.)

sentences.zh: 堂陽在堂水之陽，今兾州縣，故城在今兾州鹿城縣西南。

translations.literal: Tongyang was on the north bank of the Tang River, now Jizhou county; the ancient city is southwest of modern Luocheng County in Jizhou.
translations.idiomatic: Tongyang was situated on the north bank of the Tang River and corresponds to modern Jizhou; its ancient administrative seat lay southwest of present-day Luocheng in Jizhou.

sentences.zh: 貰音時夜反。〉王莽和成卒正邳彤亦舉郡降。

translations.literal: (The pronunciation of 'Shi' is indicated by the reverse fanqie of shi-ye.)
translations.idiomatic: (The character 'Shi' is pronounced according to the reverse fanqie of shi and ye.)

sentences.zh: 〈《東觀記》曰：「王莽分鉅鹿為和成郡。」

translations.literal: (The "Records of the Eastern Pavilion" says: "Wang Mang divided Julu to create Hedi Commandery.")
translations.idiomatic: (The 'Records of the Eastern Pavilion' notes: 'Wang Mang partitioned Julu Commandery to create the new Hedi Commandery.')

sentences.zh: 卒正，職如太守。〉又昌城人劉植，宋子人耿純，〈昌城，縣，屬信都國，故城在今兾州西北。

translations.literal: The Commander-in-Chief had duties like those of a Grand Administrator.
translations.idiomatic: The office of Commander-in-Chief carried responsibilities equivalent to those of a Grand Administrator.

sentences.zh: 宋子，縣，屬鉅鹿郡，故城在今趙州平棘縣北。〉各率宗親子弟，據其縣邑，以奉光武。

translations.literal: Songzi was a county belonging to Julu Commandery; the ancient city is north of modern Pingji County in Zhao Prefecture.
translations.idiomatic: Songzi was a county within Julu Commandery; its ancient administrative center was located north of present-day Pingji in Zhao Prefecture.

sentences.zh: 於是北降下曲陽，〈縣名，屬鉅鹿郡。

translations.literal: Thereupon he brought Xiuyang under submission to the north. (County name, belonging to Julu Commandery.)
translations.idiomatic: Guangwu then extended his control northward to Xiuyang. (Xiuyang was a county within Julu Commandery.)

sentences.zh: 常山郡有上曲陽，故此言下。〉衆稍合，樂附者至有數萬人。

translations.literal: Changshan Commandery had Shangquyang, thus this was called Xia (Lower).
translations.idiomatic: Since Changshan Commandery contained Shangquyang (Upper Quyang), this location was designated Xiaquyang (Lower Quyang).

sentences.zh: 復北擊中山，〈中山，國，一名中人亭，故城在今定州唐縣東北。

translations.literal: He again attacked Zhongshan to the north. (Zhongshan was a kingdom, also named Zhongrenting; the ancient city is northeast of modern Tang County in Dingzhou.)
translations.idiomatic: Guangwu then launched another offensive northward against Zhongshan. (Zhongshan was a kingdom, also known as Zhongrenting; its ancient capital lay northeast of present-day Tang County in Dingzhou.)

sentences.zh: 張曜中山記曰：「城中有山，故曰中山。」〉拔盧奴。

translations.literal: Zhang Yao's "Records of Zhongshan" says: "There is a mountain within the city, thus it is called Zhongshan."
translations.idiomatic: Zhang Yao's 'Records of Zhongshan' explains: 'A mountain stands within the city walls, which is why it is named Zhongshan (Central Mountain).'

sentences.zh: 〈縣名，屬中山國，故城在今定州安喜縣。

translations.literal: (County name, belonging to Zhongshan kingdom; the ancient city is in modern Anhui County in Dingzhou.)
