translations.idiomatic: (Lunü was a county within Zhongshan kingdom; its ancient administrative seat corresponds to modern Anhui in Dingzhou.)

sentences.zh: 水經注曰：「縣有黑水故池，水黑曰盧，不流曰奴，因以為名。」〉所過發奔命兵，〈《前書》音義曰：「舊時郡國皆有材官、騎士，若有急難，權取驍勇者聞命奔赴，故謂之『奔命』。」

translations.literal: The "Commentary on the Water Classic" says: "The county has an ancient pool of black water; black water is called 'lu', and not flowing is called 'nu'; thus it was named accordingly."
translations.idiomatic: The 'Commentary on the Water Classic' notes: 'The county contains an ancient pool of black water. Black water is termed "lu", while stagnant water is called "nu"—hence the name Lunü.'

sentences.zh: 南擊新市、真定、元氏、防子，皆下之，〈新市，縣，屬鉅鹿郡，故城在今恒州東北。

translations.literal: He attacked southward at Xinshi, Zhending, Yuanshi, and Fangzi; all surrendered. (Xinshi was a county belonging to Julu Commandery; the ancient city is northeast of modern Hengzhou.)
translations.idiomatic: Guangwu launched attacks southward against Xinshi, Zhending, Yuanshi, and Fangzi, all of which surrendered to him. (Xinshi was a county within Julu Commandery; its ancient administrative seat lay northeast of present-day Hengzhou.)

sentences.zh: 元氏、房子，屬常山郡，並今趙州縣也。

translations.literal: Yuanshi and Fangzi belonged to Changshan Commandery; both are now Zhao Prefecture counties.
translations.idiomatic: Yuanshi and Fangzi were both counties within Changshan Commandery, corresponding to modern Zhao Prefecture counties.

sentences.zh: 防與房古字通用。〉因入趙界。

translations.literal: Fang and Fang are interchangeable ancient characters.
translations.idiomatic: The characters 'Fang' and 'Fang' were used interchangeably in ancient texts.

sentences.zh: 時王郎大將李育屯柏人，〈縣名，屬趙國，今邢州縣，故城在縣之西北。〉漢兵不知而進，前部偏將朱浮、鄧禹為育所破，亡失輜重。

translations.literal: At that time, Wang Lang's great general Li Yu was stationed at Bairen. (County name, belonging to Zhao kingdom; now Xingzhou county; the ancient city is northwest of the county.)
translations.idiomatic: Wang Lang's chief general Li Yu was at that time encamped at Bairen. (Bairen was a county within the Zhao kingdom, corresponding to modern Xingzhou; its ancient administrative center lay northwest of the modern county seat.)

sentences.zh: 光武在後聞之，收浮、禹散卒，與育戰於郭門，大破之，盡得其所獲。

translations.literal: Guangwu heard of this from behind, gathered Zhu Fu and Deng Yu's scattered troops, and fought against Yu at the outer city gate; he greatly defeated him and recovered all that had been captured.
translations.idiomatic: Guangwu, following behind, learned of the defeat. He rallied Zhu Fu and Deng Yu's scattered forces and engaged Li Yu in battle at the city gates, decisively routing him and recovering all the captured supplies.

sentences.zh: 育還保城，攻之不下，於是引兵拔廣阿。

translations.literal: Yu retreated to defend the city; attacking it they could not take it, thus they led troops to seize Guang'e.
translations.idiomatic: Li Yu retreated to defend Bairen, but Guangwu's forces could not breach its walls. They therefore diverted to capture Guang'e instead.

sentences.zh: 〈縣名，屬鉅鹿郡，故城在今趙州象城縣西北。〉會上谷太守耿況、漁陽太守彭寵〈上谷，郡，故城在今媯州懷戎縣。

translations.literal: (County name, belonging to Julu Commandery; the ancient city is northwest of modern Xiangcheng County in Zhao Prefecture.)
translations.idiomatic: (Guang'e was a county within Julu Commandery; its ancient administrative seat lay northwest of present-day Xiangcheng in Zhao Prefecture.)

sentences.zh: 漁陽，郡，在漁水之陽，今幽州縣。〉各遣其將吳漢、寇恂等將突騎來助擊王郎，〈突騎，言能衝突軍陣。

translations.literal: Yuyang was a commandery on the north bank of the Yu River; now Youzhou county.
translations.idiomatic: Yuyang Commandery was situated north of the Yu River, corresponding to modern Youzhou.

sentences.zh: 有常侍曹尚書，主丞相御史事；

translations.literal: There was the Chamberlain Section Palace Attendant, in charge of Chancellor and Censor matters;
translations.idiomatic: The office included the Palace Attendant of the Chamberlain Section, responsible for affairs concerning the Chancellor and Censors;

sentences.zh: 二千石尚書，主刺史、二千石事；

translations.literal: the 2,000 Piculs Palace Attendant, in charge of Inspector and 2,000 piculs officials' matters;
translations.idiomatic: the Palace Attendant for 2,000 Piculs Officials, overseeing the affairs of Inspectors and 2,000 piculs ranked administrators;

sentences.zh: 戶曹尚書，主人庶上書事；

translations.literal: the Household Section Palace Attendant, in charge of commoners' memorial matters;
translations.idiomatic: the Palace Attendant of the Household Section, handling memorials submitted by common people;

sentences.zh: 主客尚書，主外國四夷事；

translations.literal: the Reception Palace Attendant, in charge of foreign countries and four barbarians matters;
translations.idiomatic: the Palace Attendant for Guests, responsible for diplomatic relations with foreign states and the four barbarian tribes;

sentences.zh: 成帝加三公尚書，主斷獄事。

translations.literal: Emperor Cheng added the Three Excellencies Palace Attendant, in charge of judging legal cases.)
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Cheng added the Palace Attendant for the Three Excellencies, responsible for adjudicating legal matters.)

sentences.zh: 僕射，秦官也。

translations.literal: The Palace Attendant was a Qin office.)
translations.idiomatic: The position of Palace Attendant originated as a Qin dynasty office.)

sentences.zh: 僕，主也。

translations.literal: Pu means master.)
translations.idiomatic: The term 'pu' signifies a chief or master.)

sentences.zh: 古者重武事，每官必有主射以督課之。」

translations.literal: In ancient times they valued military affairs; every office necessarily had a Chief Archer to supervise and assess them.")
translations.idiomatic: In antiquity, military matters were highly valued; every office was required to have a Chief Archer to oversee and evaluate performance.")

sentences.zh: 謝躬為尚書僕射。〉光武因大饗士卒，遂東圍鉅鹿。

translations.literal: Xie Gong was the Palace Attendant of the Palace Secretariat.)
translations.idiomatic: Xie Gong served as Palace Attendant of the Palace Secretariat.)

sentences.zh: 王郎守將王饒堅守，月餘不下。

translations.literal: Wang Lang's defending general Wang Rao firmly defended it; after more than a month they could not take it.
translations.idiomatic: Wang Lang's garrison commander Wang Rao held out resolutely; Guangwu's forces could not breach the defenses for over a month.

sentences.zh: 郎遣將倪宏、劉奉〈倪音五兮反。〉率數萬人救鉅鹿，光武逆戰於南䜌，〈縣名，屬鉅鹿郡，故城在今邢州柏人縣東北。

translations.literal: Lang sent generals Ni Hong and Liu Feng. (Ni is pronounced as the reverse fanqie of wu-xi.)
translations.idiomatic: Wang Lang dispatched his generals Ni Hong and Liu Feng. (The character 'Ni' is pronounced according to the reverse fanqie of wu and xi.)

sentences.zh: 左傳齊國夏伐晉取欒，即其地也。

translations.literal: In the Zuozhuan, when Duke Guo of Qi attacked Jin and took Luan, it was this place.)
translations.idiomatic: The Zuozhuan records that when Duke Guo of Qi invaded Jin and captured Luan, it was this very location.)

sentences.zh: 其後南徙，故加「南」。

translations.literal: Later it moved south, thus they added "Nan" (South).)
translations.idiomatic: Afterward, the settlement relocated southward, hence the addition of the character 'Nan' (South).)

sentences.zh: 今俗謂之倫城，聲之轉也。

translations.literal: Today the common people call it Lun City, a transformation of the sound.)
translations.idiomatic: In modern times, locals refer to it as Lun City, a phonetic evolution of the name.)

sentences.zh: 䜌音力全反。〉斬首數千級。

translations.literal: (Pi is pronounced as the reverse fanqie of li-quan.)
translations.idiomatic: (The character 'Pi' is pronounced according to the reverse fanqie of li and quan.)

sentences.zh: 四月，進圍邯鄲，連戰破之。

translations.literal: In the fourth month, they advanced to besiege Handan, and in successive battles defeated it.
translations.idiomatic: In the fourth month, Guangwu advanced to lay siege to Handan, defeating Wang Lang's forces in a series of engagements.

sentences.zh: 五月甲辰，拔其城，誅王郎。

translations.literal: On the Jia Chen day of the fifth month, they captured the city and executed Wang Lang.
translations.idiomatic: On the Jia Chen day of the fifth month, Guangwu's forces stormed the city and put Wang Lang to death.

sentences.zh: 收文書，得吏人與郎交關謗毀者數千章。

translations.literal: They seized the documents and obtained several thousand memorials from officials and people who had secretly communicated with and slandered Lang.
translations.idiomatic: Upon seizing the official documents, they uncovered thousands of memorials from officials and citizens who had secretly corresponded with Wang Lang and spread slander against Guangwu.

sentences.zh: 光武不省，會諸將軍燒之，曰：「令反側子自安。」

translations.literal: Guangwu did not examine them; the various generals assembled and burned them, saying: "Let the wavering ones be at peace."
translations.idiomatic: Guangwu refused to examine the documents. His generals gathered and burned them all, declaring, 'Let those who were unsettled now find peace.'

sentences.zh: 〈反側，不安也。

translations.literal: (Fan-ce means unrest.)
translations.idiomatic: (The term 'fan-ce' signifies restlessness or disloyalty.)

sentences.zh: 詩國風曰：「展轉反側。」

translations.literal: As in the "Guo Feng" of the Book of Songs: "Tossing and turning."
translations.idiomatic: As expressed in the 'Guo Feng' section of the Book of Songs: 'Tossing and turning in unrest.'

sentences.zh: 更始遣侍御史持節立光武為蕭王，〈蕭，縣，屬沛郡，今徐州縣也。

translations.literal: Gengshi sent the Palace Steward holding the tally to establish Guangwu as King of Xiao. (Xiao was a county belonging to Pei Commandery, now Xuzhou county.)
translations.idiomatic: The Gengshi Emperor dispatched a Palace Steward bearing the imperial tally to enfeoff Guangwu as King of Xiao. (Xiao was a county within Pei Commandery, corresponding to modern Xuzhou.)

sentences.zh: 《續漢書》曰：「更始使侍御史黃黨封上為蕭王。」〉悉令罷兵詣行在所。

translations.literal: The "Continued Book of Han" says: "Gengshi sent the Palace Steward Huang Dang to enfeoff the Emperor as King of Xiao.")
translations.idiomatic: The 'Continued Book of Han' records: 'The Gengshi Emperor sent Palace Steward Huang Dang to enfeoff Guangwu as King of Xiao.")

sentences.zh: 〈蔡邕獨斷曰：「天子以四海為家，故謂所居為行在所。」〉光武辭以河北未平，不就徵。

translations.literal: (Cai Yong's "Monopoly of Interpretations" says: "The Son of Heaven considers the four seas as his home, thus his residence is called the 'xingzaisu'."
translations.idiomatic: (Cai Yong's 'Monopoly of Interpretations' explains: 'The Son of Heaven regards the four seas as his domain, therefore his current location is referred to as the 'xingzaisu' or imperial residence.'

sentences.zh: 自是始貳於更始。

translations.literal: From this point forward, he began to be disloyal to Gengshi.
translations.idiomatic: From this point onward, Guangwu began to harbor doubts about Gengshi's rule.

sentences.zh: 〈貳，離異也。

translations.literal: (The character 'er' means to be disloyal or estranged.)
translations.idiomatic: (The term 'er' signifies disloyalty or separation.)

sentences.zh: 是時長安政亂，四方背叛。

translations.literal: At this time, political affairs in Chang'an were in chaos, and the four quarters were rebelling.
translations.idiomatic: At this time, Chang'an was in political turmoil, and rebellions were breaking out across the empire.

sentences.zh: 梁王劉永擅命睢陽，〈縣名，屬梁郡，今宋州也。

translations.literal: Liang King Liu Yong arbitrarily issued commands in Suiyang. (Suiyang is a county name, belonging to Liang Commandery, now Songzhou.)
translations.idiomatic: King Liang Liu Yong took it upon himself to issue decrees from Suiyang. (Suiyang was a county in Liang Commandery, corresponding to present-day Songzhou.)

sentences.zh: 擅，專也。〉公孫述稱王巴蜀，〈蜀有巴郡，故緫言之。

translations.literal: The character 'shan' means to act arbitrarily or exclusively.
translations.idiomatic: The term 'shan' signifies acting on one's own authority.

sentences.zh: 黎丘楚地，故稱楚黎王。」

translations.literal: Liqiu is in Chu territory, hence he called himself King of Chu and Li.'')
translations.idiomatic: Liqiu lay in Chu lands, which is why he styled himself King of Chu and Li.'')

sentences.zh: 黎丘故城在今襄州率道縣北。〉張步起琅邪，〈郡有琅邪山，故城，今海州朐山縣東北。

translations.literal: The ancient city of Liqiu is located north of Shudao County in present-day Xiangzhou.)
translations.idiomatic: The ruins of ancient Liqiu lie north of Shudao County in modern Xiangzhou.)

sentences.zh: 有夷山，故曰夷陵，今硤州縣也，故城在今縣西北。〉並置將帥，侵略郡縣。

translations.literal: There is Mount Yi, hence it is called Yiling; it is now Xiazhou County, with its ancient city northwest of the present county.)
translations.idiomatic: The place takes its name from Mount Yi, hence 'Yiling'; it's now Xiazhou County, with its old city lying northwest of the modern county.)

sentences.zh: 又別號諸賊銅馬、大肜、高湖、重連、鐵脛、大搶、尤來、上江、青犢、五校、檀郷、五幡、五樓、富平、獲索等，〈諸賊或以山川土地為名，或以軍容彊盛為號。

translations.literal: Additionally, the various bandits were separately known as the Copper Horse, Great Vessel, High Lake, Heavy Link, Iron Shin, Great Robber, Especially Come, Upper Jiang, Green Calf, Five Schools, Tan Township, Five Banners, Five Towers, Rich Plain, and Obtain Rope groups. (The various bandits sometimes took names from mountains, rivers, and lands, or from their military appearance and strength.)
translations.idiomatic: The bandits also went by various names: Copper Horse, Great Vessel, High Lake, Heavy Link, Iron Shin, Great Robber, Especially Come, Upper Jiang, Green Calf, Five Schools, Tan Township, Five Banners, Five Towers, Rich Plain, and Obtain Rope. (Some took their names from geographical features, others from their formidable military bearing.)

sentences.zh: 銅馬賊帥東山荒禿、上淮況等，大肜渠帥樊重，尤來渠帥樊崇，五校賊帥高扈，檀郷賊帥董次仲，五樓賊帥張文，富平賊帥徐少，獲索賊帥古師郎等，並見東觀記。〉各領部曲，〈《續漢志》曰：「大將軍營有五部，部三校尉。

translations.literal: The Copper Horse bandit leaders were Dongshan Huangtu, Shang Huaikuang, and others; the Great Vessel leader was Fan Zhong; the Especially Come leader was Fan Chong; the Five Schools bandit leader was Gao Hu; the Tan Township bandit leader was Dong Cizhong; the Five Towers bandit leader was Zhang Wen; the Rich Plain bandit leader was Xu Shao; the Obtain Rope bandit leader was Gu Shilang; and others—all appear in the Dongguan Record.)
translations.idiomatic: The leaders of the Copper Horse bandits included Dongshan Huangtu and Shang Huaikuang; Fan Zhong led the Great Vessel group; Fan Chong led Especially Come; Gao Hu led Five Schools; Dong Cizhong led Tan Township; Zhang Wen led Five Towers; Xu Shao led Rich Plain; Gu Shilang led Obtain Rope—and all these are recorded in the Dongguan Record.)

sentences.zh: 部下有曲，曲有軍候一人。」〉衆合數百萬人，所在寇掠。

translations.literal: Under each bu there are qu, and each qu has one army inspector.
translations.idiomatic: Each division contains companies, and each company has one military officer.

sentences.zh: 光武將擊之，先遣吳漢北發十郡兵。

translations.literal: Guangwu was about to strike against them; he first sent Wu Han north to mobilize troops from ten commanderies.
translations.idiomatic: Guangwu prepared to attack them, first dispatching Wu Han north to raise soldiers from ten commanderies.

sentences.zh: 幽州牧苗曾不從，漢遂斬曾而發其衆。

translations.literal: Youzhou Governor Miao Zeng refused to comply; Han then executed Zeng and mobilized his troops.
translations.idiomatic: Governor Miao Zeng of Youzhou refused to obey; Wu Han had him executed and then raised his forces.

sentences.zh: 秋，光武擊銅馬於鄡，〈縣名，屬鉅鹿郡，故城在今兾州鹿城縣東。

translations.literal: In autumn, Guangwu attacked the Copper Horse bandits at Kuang. (Kuang is a county name, belonging to Julu Commandery; its ancient city is east of Luocheng County in present-day Jizhou.)
translations.idiomatic: That autumn, Guangwu struck at the Copper Horse bandits near Kuang. (Kuang was a county in Julu Commandery; its old city lies east of Luocheng County in modern Jizhou.)

sentences.zh: 鄡音苦堯反。

translations.literal: The character 'Kuang' is pronounced according to the reverse fanqie of Ku and Yao.)
translations.idiomatic: Kuang is pronounced with the sound of 'ku yao' reversed.)

sentences.zh: 竹書紀年曰：「衞鞅封于鄡。」

translations.literal: The Bamboo Annals states: 'Wei Yang was enfeoffed at Kuang.'')
translations.idiomatic: According to the Bamboo Annals: 'Wei Yang received Kuang as his fief.'')

sentences.zh: 臣賢案：下文云「吳漢將突騎來會清陽」，又「追至館陶」，並與鄡相近。

translations.literal: Minister Xian's note: The text below mentions 'Wu Han led the shock cavalry to meet at Qingyang' and 'pursued to Guantao,' both of which are near Kuang.)
translations.idiomatic: Comment by Minister Xian: Later passages mention Wu Han bringing his shock troops to rendezvous at Qingyang and pursuing the enemy to Guantao, both locations near Kuang.)

sentences.zh: 俗本多誤作「鄔」，而蕭該音一古反，云屬太原郡，臧矜音作鄢，一建反，云屬襄陽郡，並誤也。〉吳漢將突騎來會清陽。

translations.literal: Popular editions often mistakenly write it as 'Wu,' and Xiao Gai pronounces it 'yi gu' reversed, claiming it belongs to Taiyuan Commandery; Zang Jin pronounces it as 'Yan' with 'jian' reversed, claiming it belongs to Xiangyang Commandery—all are errors.)
translations.idiomatic: Common printed versions frequently miswrite it as 'Wu,' with Xiao Gai giving it the pronunciation 'yi gu' reversed and claiming it belongs to Taiyuan Commandery, while Zang Jin pronounces it 'Yan' with 'jian' reversed and claims it's in Xiangyang Commandery—all incorrect.)

sentences.zh: 〈縣名，屬清河郡，今貝州縣，故城在州西北。〉賊數挑戰，〈挺身獨戰也，古謂之致師，見左傳。

translations.literal: (Qingyang is a county name, belonging to Qinghe Commandery; it is now Beizhou County, with its ancient city northwest of the present prefecture.)
translations.idiomatic: (Qingyang was a county in Qinghe Commandery; it's now Beizhou County, with its old city lying northwest of the modern prefecture.)

sentences.zh: 挑音徒了反。〉光武堅營自守；

translations.literal: The character 'tiao' is pronounced according to the reverse fanqie of Tu and Liao.)
translations.idiomatic: Tiao is pronounced with the sound of 'tu liao' reversed.)

sentences.zh: 有出鹵掠者，輒擊取之，〈鹵與虜同。

translations.literal: whenever bandits sallied forth to plunder, he would immediately strike and capture them. (Lu is the same as bu or plunder.)
translations.idiomatic: Whenever bandits ventured out to raid, he promptly attacked and seized them. (The term 'lu' has the same meaning as 'bu' or to plunder.)

sentences.zh: 郭璞注爾雅曰：「掠，奪取也。」〉絕其粮道。

translations.literal: Guo Pu's commentary on the Erya states: Lue means to seize or take by force.
translations.idiomatic: In Guo Pu's annotation of the Erya: Lue means to seize or take by force.

sentences.zh: 積月餘日，賊食盡，夜遁去，追至館陶，大破之。

translations.literal: After more than a month had passed, the bandits ran out of food; they fled by night, and Guangwu pursued them to Guantao, where he inflicted a major defeat upon them.
translations.idiomatic: After accumulating more than a month of this, the bandits exhausted their provisions; they slipped away under cover of darkness, but Guangwu pursued them to Guantao and dealt them a crushing blow.

sentences.zh: 〈館陶，縣，屬魏郡，今魏州縣。〉受降未盡，而高湖、重連從東南來，與銅馬餘衆合，光武復與大戰於蒲陽，悉破降之，封其渠帥為列侯。

translations.literal: (Guantao is a county, belonging to Wei Commandery; it is now Weizhou County.)
translations.idiomatic: (Guantao was a county in Wei Commandery; it's now Weizhou County.)

sentences.zh: 〈《前書》音義曰「蒲陽山，蒲水所出」，在今定州北平縣西北。

translations.literal: (The Phonetics and Meanings of the Book of Han states: 'Puyang Mountain is the source of the Pu River,' located northwest of Beiping County in present-day Dingzhou.)
translations.idiomatic: (According to the Phonetics and Meanings of the Book of Han: 'Puyang Mountain is where the Pu River originates,' lying northwest of Beiping County in modern Dingzhou.)

sentences.zh: 本或作「滿陽」。

translations.literal: Some versions write it as 'Manyang.')
translations.idiomatic: Some editions have 'Manyang' instead.)

sentences.zh: 渠，大也。

translations.literal: The character 'qu' means great or chief.
translations.idiomatic: The term 'qu' signifies great or chief.

sentences.zh: 尚書：「殲厥渠魁。」

translations.literal: The Book of Documents states: Slaughter their chief leaders.
translations.idiomatic: As stated in the Book of Documents: Slaughter their chief leaders.

sentences.zh: 列侯即徹侯也。

translations.literal: Liehou is the same as Chehou.
translations.idiomatic: The title 'Liehou' is equivalent to 'Chehou'.

sentences.zh: 稱列者，言見序列也。〉降者猶不自安，光武知其意，勑令各歸營勒兵，乃自乘輕騎按行部陳。

translations.literal: The term 'lie' means they appear in sequence.
translations.idiomatic: The designation 'lie' indicates they are listed in order.

sentences.zh: 降者更相語曰：「蕭王推赤心置人腹中，安得不投死乎！」

translations.literal: The defectors said to one another: 'King Xiao lays bare his heart and places it in people's bellies—how can we not devote ourselves to death for him!'
translations.idiomatic: The surrendered fighters remarked among themselves: 'King Xiao exposes his true heart and places it deep within others—how can we help but pledge our lives to him!'

sentences.zh: 〈投死猶言致死。〉由是皆服。

translations.literal: (The phrase 'tou si' is equivalent to 'devoting oneself to death.'
translations.idiomatic: (The expression 'tou si' means to give one's life completely.

sentences.zh: 悉將降人分配諸將，衆遂數十萬，故關西號光武為「銅馬帝」。

translations.literal: He distributed all the surrendered troops among his various generals; his forces thus grew to several hundred thousand men, hence west of the passes they called Guangwu the 'Copper Horse Emperor.'
translations.idiomatic: He assigned all the defectors to serve under his different commanders; his army thereby swelled to several hundred thousand, which is why west of the passes they dubbed Guangwu the 'Copper Horse Emperor.'

sentences.zh: 赤眉別帥與大肜、青犢十餘萬衆在射犬，〈《續漢志》曰野王縣有射犬聚，故城在今懷州武德縣北也。〉光武進擊，大破之，衆皆散走。

translations.literal: A separate Red Eyebrow commander together with Great Vessel and Green Calf forces numbering more than one hundred thousand were at Shequan. (The Continued Book of Han states that Yehuang County had the Shequan settlement; its ancient city is north of Wude County in present-day Huaizhou.)
translations.idiomatic: A Red Eyebrow division commander, along with Great Vessel and Green Calf troops totaling over one hundred thousand men, was positioned at Shequan. (According to the Continued Book of Han, Yehuang County contained the Shequan settlement; its old site lies north of Wude County in modern Huaizhou.)

sentences.zh: 使吳漢、岑彭襲殺謝躬於鄴。

translations.literal: He sent Wu Han and Cen Peng to launch a surprise attack and kill Xie Gong at Ye.
translations.idiomatic: He dispatched Wu Han and Cen Peng to ambush and assassinate Xie Gong at Ye.

sentences.zh: 青犢、赤眉賊入函谷關，攻更始。

translations.literal: The Green Calf and Red Eyebrow bandits entered Hangu Pass and attacked Gengshi.
translations.idiomatic: The Green Calf and Red Eyebrow rebels penetrated Hangu Pass and assaulted Gengshi.

sentences.zh: 〈函谷，谷名，因谷以名關。

translations.literal: (Hangu is a valley name; the pass took its name from the valley.
translations.idiomatic: (Hangu refers to a valley; the pass was named after this valley.

sentences.zh: 舊在弘農湖城縣西，《前書》楊僕為樓船將軍，有功，恥居關外，武帝乃為徒於新安。

translations.literal: Originally located west of Hucheng County in Hongnong. The Book of Han records that Yang Pu served as General of the Tower Ships and achieved merit; ashamed to dwell outside the pass, Emperor Wu therefore moved it to Xin'an.
translations.idiomatic: It was formerly situated west of Hucheng County in Hongnong Commandery. As recorded in the Book of Han, Yang Pu served as General of the Tower Ships and distinguished himself; mortified at residing beyond the pass, Emperor Wu consequently relocated it to Xin'an.

sentences.zh: 故關在今洛州新安縣之東。〉光武乃遣鄧禹率六裨將引兵而西，以乘更始、赤眉之亂。

translations.literal: The old pass is east of Xin'an County in present-day Luozhou.)
translations.idiomatic: The former pass lies east of Xin'an County in modern Luozhou.)

sentences.zh: 時更始使大司馬朱鮪、舞陰王李軼等屯洛陽，〈舞陰，縣，屬南陽郡，故城在今唐州沘陽縣西北。〉光武亦令馮異守孟津以拒之。

translations.literal: At this time, Gengshi sent Grand Marshal Zhu Wei and King of Wuyin Li Yi and others to encamp at Luoyang. (Wuyin is a county, belonging to Nanyang Commandery; its ancient city is northwest of Biyang County in present-day Tangzhou.) Guangwu also ordered Feng Yi to defend Mengjin to oppose them.
translations.idiomatic: At this juncture, Gengshi dispatched Grand Marshal Zhu Wei and King Li Yi of Wuyin and others to station troops at Luoyang. (Wuyin was a county in Nanyang Commandery; its old site lies northwest of Biyang County in modern Tangzhou.) Guangwu likewise commanded Feng Yi to hold Mengjin against them.

sentences.zh: 〈孔安國注尚書云：「孟，地名，在洛北，都道所湊，古今以為津。」

translations.literal: (Kong Anguo's commentary on the Book of Documents states: 'Meng is a place name, north of Luo, where all roads converge; throughout history it has been known as a ford.')
translations.idiomatic: (In Kong Anguo's annotation of the Book of Documents: 'Meng refers to a location north of Luo where all routes meet; it has served as a crossing point from ancient times to the present.')

sentences.zh: 論衡曰：「武王伐紂，八百諸侯同於此盟，故曰盟津。」

translations.literal: The Lunheng states: 'When King Wu attacked Zhou, eight hundred lords allied here, hence it is called Alliance Ford.'
translations.idiomatic: According to the Lunheng: 'When King Wu campaigned against Zhou, eight hundred feudal lords formed their covenant here, which is why it's called Alliance Ford.'

sentences.zh: 俗名治戍津，今河陽縣津也。

translations.literal: In common parlance it is called Garrison Ford; it is now the ford at Heyang County.
translations.idiomatic: Locally it's known as Garrison Ford; today it's the crossing at Heyang County.

sentences.zh: 光武北擊尤來、大搶、五幡於元氏，追至右北平，連破之。

translations.literal: Guangwu struck north against Especially Come, Great Robber, and Five Banners at Yuanshi, pursued them to Right Beiping, and successively defeated them.
translations.idiomatic: Guangwu launched a northern offensive against Especially Come, Great Robber, and Five Banners at Yuanshi, chased them to Right Beiping, and won repeated victories.
